Notes: No new policy. There are lockdown and lockout areas in the NT but schools do not seem to be affected. Schools are still in-person with certain precautions. Ex. In NT school excursions and extra-curricular activities outside of school grounds at government schools have been paused for the first 4 weeks of Term 1, 2022.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220216000422/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/education-and-childcare/nt

Lockdowns have ended but there are lock-ins in place for Ampilatwatja, Palumpa, Milingimbi, Milikapiti, Elcho and Wessel Islands. The lock-in applies until 6 February 2022.    You canât leave a lock-in area unless you are an authorised officer or essential worker. You donât need to stay at home during the lock-in â unless you are a COVID-19 positive case or a close contact of a positive case â but you canât leave the community without an exemption.    Proof of vaccination is required to enter:  - Bars, pubs and nightclubs licensed to sell and consume liquor on premises  - Clubs licensed to sell and consume liquor on premises  - Casinos and licensed gaming venues  - Restaurants with a liquor licence  - Cinema, theatre, concert, music or dance hall.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102123/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102206/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/slow-spread/current-restrictions

There are no current lockdowns or lockouts in place which would limit workplaces. Businesses can allow staff to work from home at their discretion.    Although the public health orders now permit entry to businesses for people who are not fully vaccinated, some businesses may make it a condition of entry that you are fully vaccinated or wear a face mask. Some businesses are required to use the COVID-Safe Check-In system. This varies between regions but examples include pubs, clubs, casinos, restaurants, cinemas, and large ticketed events.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220218195215/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt  https://web.archive.org/web/20220218201245/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/business/nsw-rules  https://web.archive.org/web/20220218200144/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/slow-spread/current-restrictions

Lock-ins that are in place restrict travel between regions but universally proof of vaccination is required events of differing maximum quotas. Ex. in the NT Community and recreation centres, play centres and public libraries can operate. Proof of vaccination is required to enter:  - pubs and clubs  - casinos  - restaurants  - cinemas and theatres  - ticketed events for more than 500 people in urban centres or more than 100 people in non-urban centres    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205105653/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/entertainment-and-amusement-venues/nt  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102123/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt

In NSW - Music festivals are still prohibited. If you are not fully vaccinated, you cannot visit a recreation or entertainment facility or attend an outdoor event.    If you are vaccinated: Entertainment facilities, such as a cinema, theatre, musical hall, concert hall, dance hall, drive-in cinemas can open to fully vaccinated people. Indoor and outdoor major recreation facilities, including stadiums, theme parks, zoos, aquariums and showgrounds can open.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211214172332/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/entertainment-and-amusement-venues/nsw

Lock-ins that are in place restrict travel between regions but universally proof of vaccination is required events of differing maximum quotas. Ex. in the NT Community and recreation centres, play centres and public libraries can operate. Proof of vaccination is required to enter:  - pubs and clubs  - casinos  - restaurants  - cinemas and theatres  - ticketed events for more than 500 people in urban centres or more than 100 people in non-urban centres    Events with less than 500 people don't require a checklist or safety plan, however the physical distancing and hygiene principles should still be considered and implemented.    Events with 500 to 1000 people do require completion of a COVID-19 Small Event Checklist. The organiser of the event must also appoint a COVID-19 Safety Supervisor and display a QR code or alternate method of checking in.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205105653/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/entertainment-and-amusement-venues/nt  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102123/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt

In South Australia up to 50 people are allowed in a home, including residents.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220218203050/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/gatherings-and-work/sa

Lockins are in place in the NT areas. Although regulations vary, all interstate travel is restricted to some degree. All travelers to the Northern Territory must complete a border entry form. Entry is prohibited from current hotspots or public exposure sites without a prior approved exemption attached to your border entry form. The government of Western Australia (WA) has enacted a controlled interstate border arrangement. All travelers must register online before traveling to Western Australia. The areas where travelers have spent time prior to arriving in Western Australia determine conditions of their entry and any possible quarantine, vaccination, and/or COVID-19 testing requirements. Currently all areas of AUS are considered an extreme risk. You are not permitted to enter without an approval through G2G Pass (external link). Exemptions are restricted to Commonwealth, State and specialist functions only; If permitted entry, you will be directed to undertake 14 days hotel quarantine at a Government approved quarantine facility at your own expense.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220107081429/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102123/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102206/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/slow-spread/current-restrictions

Until 11:59pm, Thursday 3 March 2022, people canât enter or exit parts of the Northern Territory that are known as designated areas.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220218195215/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt

No new policy. Continuing from 15 December AUS reopens the borders to fully vaccinated international students and Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa holders. Continuing policy restricts other travelers to Australia to fully vaccinated Australians and permanent residents.     All inbound passengers must also provide proof of vaccination status before arrival through the Australia Travel Declaration, unless they are a child under the age of 12 years and 3 months. It is important to note that previous infection with COVID-19 is not considered a medical contraindication for COVID-19 vaccination.    Passengers providing a medical certificate to provide this proof must ensure that the medical certificate is in English and includes the following information:    -their name (this must match their travel identification documents)  -date of medical consultation and details of their medical practitioner  -details that clearly outline that they have a medical condition that means they cannot receive a COVID-19 vaccination (vaccination is contraindicated).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116005735/https://www.health.gov.au/health-alerts/covid-19/international-travel/inbound  https://web.archive.org/web/20220106102244/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No new policies. National policy outlines recommended guidelines to protect the elderly along a three tiered system. The visitation restrictions and guidelines for residential aged care facilities follow social distancing, vaccination and COVID screening norms. It is up to providers to manage and mitigate COVID-19 risks to aged care residents, including the risks that isolation poses to their physical, social and emotional wellbeing. Face-to-face get togethers between residents, family members and friends should be facilitated where they can be undertaken safely and are permitted under public health orders. Residents of an aged care facility have the right to choose to have vaccinations or not.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220129111557/https://www.health.gov.au/node/18602/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-people-in-residential-aged-care-facilities-and-visitors  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129111557/https://www.agedcarequality.gov.au/sites/default/files/media/letter-commissioner-residential-approved-providers-being-prepared-for-covid-19-outbreak-22-december-2021.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210415104420/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/11/coronavirus-covid-19-national-aged-care-guidance-escalation-tiers-and-aged-care-provider-responses.pdf

Phase 2 of reintroducing in-person learning for Bruneian students has commenced on January 17, 2022.    Originally,  "The first phase will begin on January 3, 2022.     The minister explained that in-person teaching and learning for secondary students in Year 10 and Year 11 will be conducted five times a week, including special needs students from Priority Level 1 and 2. Whereas those in Priority Level 3 will only have to attend their physical classes once a week.     For Year 12 and 13 students, as well as Priority Level 1 and 2, and special need students will also undergo face-to-face teaching and learning five times a week, while once a week in-person classes for Priority Level 3 students.     âMeanwhile, teaching and learning for the remaining students will be made via online or Home Learning Pack (HLP). The first phase is planned to be carried out for at least two weeks whereby the transition towards the second phase depending if there is no increase in the spread of serious cases of infections among the students, teachers and staff as well as on the advice of the COVID-19 Steering Committeeâ, the minister explained.     The minister shared that the second phase is expected to begin on January 17, 2022. However, its implementation will depend on the current Covid-19 situation as well.     In the second phase, said the minister, in-person lessons will be carried out five times a week for students who have completed two doses of COVID-19 vaccines and the increased school capacity from 40 to 100 per cent. This is to be implemented for secondary school students from Year 7 to 11, including special need students in Priority Level 1 and 2. Those in Priority Level 3 will have to attend their physical classes thrice a week, and Year 12 and 13 students, including special needs in Priority Level 1 and 2. Classes for special needs students in Priority Level 3 will be carried out thrice a week.     Lessons for students aged 5 to 11 who have yet to receive their vaccination will continue via online and HLP.     âStudents who continue to have difficulties with online learning will be continued to be supported by the school through the provision of HLPâ, the minister stated. "    Additionally, from the frst Scoop report,   "Only fully vaccinated teachers and students can return to primary and secondary schools, sixth form centres and higher education institutions.    Some 98 percent of teachers are fully jabbed while 80 percent of students aged 12-17 have received two vaccine doses, according to education ministry figures.    All double-vaxxed students, teachers and non-teaching staff are still required to undergo antigen rapid tests once a week in the first stage of school reopening."    â    "Toddlers aged 3 to 4 can head back to kindergartens from January 17, the education minister said Wednesday.    Joining the COVID-19 news conference, Dato Hj Hamzah Hj Sulaiman said in-person lessons will be allowed for preschoolers five times a week, but attendance at kindergartens is capped at 30 percent.    To ensure the safety of preschoolers who are not authorised to receive the vaccine against COVID, only kindergartens that meet health requirements can reopen.    Kindergarten pupils will also be required to wear face masks and undergo antigen rapid tests once a week, with only those producing negative results permitted to attend in-person classes.    The minister said parents and guardians of the children must be fully jabbed and show proof of vaccination.    Double-vaccinated Year 7-9 pupils will also return to classrooms next week after a five-month hiatus due to the COVID-19 pandemic, joining Year 10-13 students who were the first group to resume face-to-face classes earlier this month."    "Brunei is still awaiting the arrival of Pfizer vaccines to inoculate children aged 5-11, who are expected to be the last group to return to schools."    See the Scoop's report, entitled "International travel to resume in January, schools to reopen in stages as Brunei enters âearly endemic phase", archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1681.0-1681.129  See the Scoop's report, entitled "Child care centres set to reopen from January 17", archived at https://archive.vn/WZHR9  See the Brunei Post's report, entitled "School reopening, in-person learning to start in stages", archived at https://archive.vn/frKFF

"Brunei is still awaiting the arrival of Pfizer vaccines to inoculate children aged 5-11, who are expected to be the last group to return to schools."    See the Scoop's report, entitled "International travel to resume in January, schools to reopen in stages as Brunei enters âearly endemic phase", archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1681.0-1681.129  See the Scoop's report, entitled "Child care centres set to reopen from January 17", archived at https://archive.vn/WZHR9  See the Brunei Post's report, entitled "School reopening, in-person learning to start in stages", archived at https://archive.vn/frKFF

Phase 2 of reintroducing in-person learning for Bruneian students has commenced on January 17, 2022.    Originally,  "The first phase will begin on January 3, 2022.     The minister explained that in-person teaching and learning for secondary students in Year 10 and Year 11 will be conducted five times a week, including special needs students from Priority Level 1 and 2. Whereas those in Priority Level 3 will only have to attend their physical classes once a week.     For Year 12 and 13 students, as well as Priority Level 1 and 2, and special need students will also undergo face-to-face teaching and learning five times a week, while once a week in-person classes for Priority Level 3 students.     âMeanwhile, teaching and learning for the remaining students will be made via online or Home Learning Pack (HLP). The first phase is planned to be carried out for at least two weeks whereby the transition towards the second phase depending if there is no increase in the spread of serious cases of infections among the students, teachers and staff as well as on the advice of the COVID-19 Steering Committeeâ, the minister explained.     The minister shared that the second phase is expected to begin on January 17, 2022. However, its implementation will depend on the current Covid-19 situation as well.     In the second phase, said the minister, in-person lessons will be carried out five times a week for students who have completed two doses of COVID-19 vaccines and the increased school capacity from 40 to 100 per cent. This is to be implemented for secondary school students from Year 7 to 11, including special need students in Priority Level 1 and 2. Those in Priority Level 3 will have to attend their physical classes thrice a week, and Year 12 and 13 students, including special needs in Priority Level 1 and 2. Classes for special needs students in Priority Level 3 will be carried out thrice a week.     Lessons for students aged 5 to 11 who have yet to receive their vaccination will continue via online and HLP.     âStudents who continue to have difficulties with online learning will be continued to be supported by the school through the provision of HLPâ, the minister stated. "    Additionally, from the frst Scoop report,   "Only fully vaccinated teachers and students can return to primary and secondary schools, sixth form centres and higher education institutions.    Some 98 percent of teachers are fully jabbed while 80 percent of students aged 12-17 have received two vaccine doses, according to education ministry figures.    All double-vaxxed students, teachers and non-teaching staff are still required to undergo antigen rapid tests once a week in the first stage of school reopening."    â    "Toddlers aged 3 to 4 can head back to kindergartens from January 17, the education minister said Wednesday.    Joining the COVID-19 news conference, Dato Hj Hamzah Hj Sulaiman said in-person lessons will be allowed for preschoolers five times a week, but attendance at kindergartens is capped at 30 percent.    To ensure the safety of preschoolers who are not authorised to receive the vaccine against COVID, only kindergartens that meet health requirements can reopen.    Kindergarten pupils will also be required to wear face masks and undergo antigen rapid tests once a week, with only those producing negative results permitted to attend in-person classes.    The minister said parents and guardians of the children must be fully jabbed and show proof of vaccination.    Double-vaccinated Year 7-9 pupils will also return to classrooms next week after a five-month hiatus due to the COVID-19 pandemic, joining Year 10-13 students who were the first group to resume face-to-face classes earlier this month."    "Brunei is still awaiting the arrival of Pfizer vaccines to inoculate children aged 5-11, who are expected to be the last group to return to schools."    See the Scoop's report, entitled "International travel to resume in January, schools to reopen in stages as Brunei enters âearly endemic phase", archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1681.0-1681.129  See the Scoop's report, entitled "Child care centres set to reopen from January 17", archived at https://archive.vn/WZHR9  See the Brunei Post's report, entitled "School reopening, in-person learning to start in stages", archived at https://archive.vn/frKFF

No change.    Business premises can operate to 75 percent or 300-people capacity, whichever is smaller, from 15 December.    "From Wednesday, all people, regardless of vaccination status, will be allowed to enter public premises or attend public events.  However, unvaccinated individuals are required to undergo ART testing at accredited ART Centres. Each test result is valid for two days.  Children under 18 who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated will be allowed to enter premises without the need for ART testing, provided that they are accompanied by a fully vaccinated adult.  Business and public premises will be allowed to hold 75 percent of their capacity, but not more than 300 people. The rule applies to:     Restaurants, cafÃ©s, food courts, markets and food stalls, cinemas, arcades, indoor playgrounds, beauty establishments, and music schools.  All indoor and outdoor sports, fitness and recreational facilities. (Only training is allowed, no sports competitions.)    Museums, galleries, libraries and senior citizens centres. (Opening hours are restricted to 8am-2pm.)   Government offices and service counters. "    Additionally, the civil service will return to normal in-person working and standard working hours.  "In the early endemic phase, civil servants will fully return to the office and normal working hours will be reinstated from 7.45am to 12.15pm and from 1.30pm to 4.30pm."    The Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1561.0-1627.41

No change.    "Public venues can increase capacity to 75%  As Brunei moves into the early endemic phase, the government also announced further easing of restrictions that will come into effect on December 15, 2021 and last until January 14, 2022.   During this period, wearing of face masks and use of the Bruhealth contact tracing app will still be mandatory, and the 10pm to 4am curfew will still be in place.   From Wednesday, all people, regardless of vaccination status, will be allowed to enter public premises or attend public events.  However, unvaccinated individuals are required to undergo ART testing at accredited ART Centres. Each test result is valid for two days.  Children under 18 who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated will be allowed to enter premises without the need for ART testing, provided that they are accompanied by a fully vaccinated adult.  Business and public premises will be allowed to hold 75 percent of their capacity, but not more than 300 people. The rule applies to:     Restaurants, cafÃ©s, food courts, markets and food stalls, cinemas, arcades, indoor playgrounds, beauty establishments, and music schools.  All indoor and outdoor sports, fitness and recreational facilities. (Only training is allowed, no sports competitions.)  Museums, galleries, libraries and senior citizens centres. (Opening hours are restricted to 8am-2pm.)  Government offices and service counters.     Members of the public are permitted to host large gatherings such as weddings, but attendance is limited to 75 percent of the venue capacity or not more than 300 people  â whichever is the smaller number. Buffet services are still not allowed, except for dome serving, and distribution of packaged meals is encouraged instead."    The Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP

No change.    With the transition to the early endemic phase, the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications have advised that transport vehicles are now limited to 75% capacity, up from 50% previously.    "2. Similarly with Public Transport such as buses, taxis and e-hailing services as well as transport of mining boats, passenger boats and passenger ships where the number of passengers is increased to 75% of the previous total passenger capacity of 50% (excluding drivers) and ensure the existence of social incarceration measures. This means that the vehicle seat capacity and number of passengers for taxis and e-Hailing vehicles such as DART service is according to the vehicle seat capacity for example the vehicle seat capacity is 5 people and the passenger limit is 3 people and so on if the capacity is 7 people and the passenger limit is 4 people."    See the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications's press release, archived in Malay, at https://archive.vn/vfs6b (see point 2 under SOP Pembukaan Sekolah Memandu dan Pengangkutan Awam)

No change.    Measures have been eased with the commencement of the early endemic phase, with the public allowed to host events up to 75% capacity/300 people, and the civil service returning to work. No change. The only country-specific exception to the total travel ban is the Reciprocal Green Lane and Vaccinated Travel Lane with Singapore. Other foreigners can only enter Brunei under specific essential travel circumstances (see below). Although a green travel list comprising of other countries such as the United Kingdom and Australia was originally envisioned for the lifting on restriction on non-essential inbound travel on Jan 1, 2022, this has now been scrapped due to concerns over the Omicron variant.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 31 Jan, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:    Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    No change. No changes/deviation; Brunei continues to maintain a systematic, coordinated public campaign re: COVID.    The government continues to maintain an overall website where citizens can access any information related to COVID.   https://archive.vn/PwOIW    There is also an overall site on the Ministry of Health's website pertaining to Covid-19 vaccination (the programme, FAQ, public health messaging).  https://archive.vn/5UFPG    The Ministry of Health continues to update COVID case numbers almost daily (especially since the recent outbreak). See, for example, 24 Jan (https://archive.vn/HzyUF) and 26 Jan (https://archive.vn/GwTTY).    There were missing updates on 27 Jan onwards.

No change.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 31 Jan,    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Brunei?  Yes.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes.  Members of the public who need to undergo a swab test for any reason are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha (RIPAS) Hospital, or other health centers where testing is provided.  The testing fee for foreigners is BND $200 [sic, current cost as per Brunei's Ministry of Health is BND $50].  More information is available here.  Test results will be delivered through SMS.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/wRZct  See the Ministry of Health press release on testing cost (22 May), archived at https://archive.vn/kU9pS

If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes.  Members of the public who need to undergo a swab test for any reason are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha (RIPAS) Hospital, or other health centers where testing is provided.  The testing fee for foreigners is BND $200 [sic, current cost as per Brunei's Ministry of Health is BND $50].  More information is available here.  Test results will be delivered through SMS.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/UGtkA  See the Ministry of Health press release on testing cost (22 May), archived at https://archive.vn/kU9pS

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting mandatory mask measures.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "Meanwhile, to address the concerns on the spread of Delta variant around the world, including in Brunei Darussalam, the Ministry of Health would also like to inform the public on the changes in the face mask guidelines:    1. Face masks are required be worn at all times, especially indoors or in crowded places either indoor or outdoor.  2. Face mask must cover the wearer's nose and mouth.  3. This directive is applicable to all individuals regardless of their vaccination status."    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 31 Jan,    "Face masks are mandatory at all times in all indoor and outdoor spaces."    This advice is confirmed in a press conference conducted by the Minister at the Prime Minister's Office, YB Dato Dr Hj Mohd Amin, on 12th December, "During this period, wearing of face masks and use of the Bruhealth contact tracing app will still be mandatory, and the 10pm to 4am curfew will still be in place."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/wRZct  See the Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP

No changes.    Brunei's Phase 3 of its Vaccination Strategy, for individuals aged 18 years and above, commenced on 05 July. "[Individuals] who wish to get the COVID-19 vaccinations during Phase 3 are required to reserve a slot".    Vaccinations have also been rolled out to adolescents aged 12 to 17 from November 8, utilising the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.    Booster shots have been available to the general public since 17 December. No change in policy since last iteration.    Additionally, under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, senior citizens of age 60 and above belong to Phase 1, alongside Bruneians studying abroad and frontliners.    The advice for elderly people to be protected via vaccinations was reiterated on 07 Aug, when Brunei first detected its first local transmission cases in over a year. "Individuals who have not yet received COVID-19 vaccination especially those at high risk such as the elderly and those with chronic diseases are advised to reserve an vaccination slot as soon as possible. Walk-ins at vaccination centres will only be allowed for senior citizens aged 60 and above or individuals with special needs."    See https://web.archive.org/web/20210111022516/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Lists/Latest%20news/NewDispForm.aspx?ID=727  See also, Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, archived on Dropbox, at https://www.dropbox.com/s/yri6djij3ieblma/BRN-202103__-MOH-VaccinationStrategyV2.pdf  See also, IMF's summary on the vaccination groups under "Brunei: Reopening of the Economy", archived at https://web.archive.org/web/20210907090853/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  See the Ministry of Health's press release dated 07 Aug, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL

2022-02-21, Annex The provincial department of education pointed out that all schools in all areas should, under the leadership of the local party committee and government, take into account the current situation of the epidemic, the requirements of prevention and control policies and the actual situation of local schools, develop and strictly implement the 2022 spring semester school opening program and the epidemic prevention and control program and emergency plans, promptly issue the notice of school opening and the requirements of returning to school for epidemic prevention and control, and make arrangements for teachers and students to return to school in a classified and orderly manner. For teachers, students and staff with a history of travel to high school risk areas in China and counties (cities and districts) where high and medium risk areas are located within 14 days before the start of the school year, they are required to suspend their return to school until the high school risk level is lifted in the relevant area. From tomorrow, informal gatherings in homes, communities, and community halls will be limited to 20 persons.    This is according to a statement released by the Minister for Commerce, Trade, Tourism and Transport, Faiyaz Koya.    He added that other venues which have been approved to operate under COVID-safe measures and or which require Care Fiji Commitment certification, including places of worship and restaurants, can host events, including weddings and other functions, at 80 percent capacity. The nationwide daily curfew from 12am to 4am has been completely lifted beginning from tonight.    Attorney-General Aiyaz Sayed-Khaiyum made the announcement in a press conference this afternoon.    Mr Sayed-Khaiyum said the curfew will not be moved nor shifted but lifted completely.    He said curfew was implemented to prevent non-essential gatherings that can spread the COVID-19 virus and allow for reliable contact tracing at certain hours in the evening.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207072252/https://www.fijitimes.com/nationwide-curfew-completely-lifted/

Beginning Wednesday, January 26, 2022, DPHSS and Community Testing Partners will prioritize COVID-19 testing across all DPHSS testing platforms to only symptomatic patients and high-risk close contacts. Due to the high volume of testing in the last several weeks, testing kits and supplies are limited. The criteria for high-risk close contacts are:        Unvaccinated or not fully vaccinated      Age 65 or older      Multiple comorbidities or multiple underlying health conditions      Moderately to severely immunocompromised condition      https://archive.fo/utSkX

Spokesperson for the COVID-19 Handling Task Force Prof. Wiku Adisasmito asked non-essential sector workers to work from home (WFH). This is an anticipation so that COVID-19 does not spread more widely in the midst of the Omicron variant.  "It is the same for those who, as a result of the demands of the situation or profession, have a high intensity of mobility and interaction. We ask that non-essential offices consider implementing WFH again as a form of anticipation of the continued increase in COVID-19 cases," he said in a press statement, Thursday (27/27). /1/2022) broadcast on the Presidential Secretariat's YouTube channel.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222084951/https://covid19.go.id/artikel/2022/01/27/satgas-pekerja-sektor-non-esensial-dihimbau-bekerja-dari-rumah-mengantisipasi-kondisi-terkini

No policy change.  Indonesia only has capacity limitations which correspond to the level of rules which apply in a given geopgraphic region - therefore, this was coded as a 1G, as essential and non-essential workplaces may open with the only requirements being capacity limitations and face-masking (no closures required - aside from when outbreaks are detected, in which case non-essential workplaces may close for 5 days to help contain outbreaks).    "In Java and Bali, the strictest level 3 rules allow nonessential and essential sectors to work on-site at a maximum of 25 and 50 percent capacity, respectively. Level 2 curbs permit nonessential and essential sectors to operate on-site at a maximum of 50 and 75 percent capacity respectively. Level 1 protocols allow nonessential and essential sectors to run at 75 and 100 percent capacity respectively. Areas enacting level 2 curbs include Jakarta and its surrounding areas."    https://archive.ph/inLbk  https://web.archive.org/web/20220228234730/https://covid19.go.id/peta-risiko

No change to previous policy.  The following measures now apply to all prefectures: Require closing restaurants and retail from 9PM and to refrain from serving alcohol after 8PM. The government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated.  The Okinawan government have also asked all inbound travellers to exercise caution and get tested when possible, in addition to refrain non-urgent movement into remote islands.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128044255/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220128045726/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220125/k10013449331000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220120163925/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220119/k10013438191000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207231538/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0203taishohoshin_1.pdf

The government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225195546/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

No change to previous policy.  Japan continues to prohibit entry for non-Visa and leisure travel from all countries. Limited Visas are being processed and all incoming flights into the country are restricted to only 3,500 people in total per day.   Japan will also be extending the quarantine period at accommodation facilities for a number of additional countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213152325/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211203/k10013374241000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207233050/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207233144/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2022C014.html

The government is looking to gradually open up borders and have announced that by the beginning of March, Japan will be permitting 5,000 individuals a day to enter the country, up from 3,500. However, leisure and non-Visa travel from all countries continues to be restricted for most travellers.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220030103/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220216/k10013486121000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220030144/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220030257/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/ca/fna/page4_005130.html

On February 25 2022, online application for entry is open in advance of the gradual relaxation of border measures beginning March 1 2022.  On March 1st, Japan will increase the maximum number of foreigners entering the country from the current 3,500 to 5,000 and gradually increase more entry.  Entry without an approved VISA sponsored by a Japanese workplace or school continues to be restricted.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220225/k10013501761000.html

No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document partially revised as of Jan 28 2022).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190020/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190012/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document partially revised as of Jan 28 2022).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190020/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190012/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document partially revised as of Jan 28 2022).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free for a one-time redemption if the parent continues to work for a year. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190020/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190012/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

Comprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190229/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190253/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/

Comprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225200557/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220225200630/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/

Period for free PCR testing have ended on January 31 in Tokyo. Some cities have also been reporting limited reagents and testing capabilities due to demand.  Testing eligibility nationwide continues to be those symptomatic or if contacted by health authority, identified as a close contact.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128054458/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220124/k10013447611000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108013225/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020775.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207233929/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213162005/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html

To reduce burden on medical facilities due increasing cases and the number of people looking to get tested, Tokyo Metropolitan Government has begun sending antigen test kits to those who apply and identify as close contacts of recently diagnosed cases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220209115924/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220208/k10013472791000.html

No change to previous policy. In Yokohama, rapid antigen test kits are also being sent out to relieve strain on PCR testing due to staff shortages at hospitals and health lab facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225201303/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220222/k10013496881000.html

Reports from other regions including Wakayama city, Matsuyama City, Miyazaki City, and Ehime Prefecture have also seen a significant increase in cases due to omicron, affecting ability to conduct comprehensive contact tracing. Some areas (for example Ehime prefecture) have offloaded regular contact tracing to the general public in an attempt to prioritize contact tracing for high risk facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207234941/https://www.the-miyanichi.co.jp/kennai/_59952.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235002/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/matsuyama-news/20220204/8000012074.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235017/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/lnews/wakayama/20220204/2040010701.html

No change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is wide spread and continues to be recommended by the government. Masks should also be worn in schools by students and faculty members, and should only be removed when eating or partaking in physical activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207205418/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

On January 28 2022, reservations for third dose vaccinations begin open for booking at mass vaccination sites operated by the Self-Defense Forces from the federal government. Booster dose vaccinations are set to begin on January 31st 2022.  The target of large-scale vaccination by the Self-Defense Forces is those who are 18 years of age or older and have a third vaccination ticket, beginning with the elderly population. Those who have not been vaccinated for more than 6 months since the second vaccination will not be vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128201721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220126/k10013451691000.html

On January 31 2022, third dose vaccination begin being distributed at Tokyo's mass vaccination site. Those who are eligible to book must have received a third-dose vaccination ticket, that is being mailed out by the government beginning with 80+ and step-wise for each age group. Third dose tickets will only be sent to those 18 years old and up, and more than 6-months must have passed since an individual's second dose.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235727/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220131/k10013457771000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235340/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220130/k10013457321000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235402/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220131/k10013458301000.html

On February 7, vaccination for third doses begin being administered at the Osaka mass vaccination site.  In Yokohama City, also Feb 7, third dose vaccination for the elderly population continues to be administered. Yokohama City has the highest number of elderly population (930,000) residing in the country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235928/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220207/k10013470791000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235927/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220207/k10013471291000.html

On Feb 10 2022, 20% of children vaccination tickets for children age 5 to 11 in the Koto Ward of Tokyo begin being sent out (~32,000 tickets). Children vaccination are set to begin on March 5 2022.  Mass vaccination for third doses in the elderly population continue to be administered. On Feb 10, the Tokyo mass vaccination site has expanded operations to inoculate 5,040 people per day and Osaka will expand to 2,500 people a day in the following week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211192435/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220210/k10013477321000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211192107/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220210/k10013476591000.html

By the end of February 2022, Japanese government is pushing to complete third dose vaccinations for elderly population in long-term care homes. The government also announces that the next priority group to become eligible for third doses in late February are education workers. Japan continues to administer third doses to residents, about 1.1 million administered per day.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025340/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220215/k10013484591000.html (education workers)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025713/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220218/k10013491621000.html (LTC homes)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025733/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220215/k10013484741000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025720/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220216/k10013487201000.html

On February 21 2022, vaccination begin for children ages 5-11 across Japan for the first time. All vaccinations are subsidized by the government. Tokyo also begins opening more vaccination clinics in schools and Shinjuku to encourage young people to get vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225202205/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220221/k10013494211000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220225202220/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220222/k10013496321000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220225095245/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220225/k10013501011000.html

Third dose vaccination begins in Tokyo's mass vaccination site on January 31 2022. In Osaka, third doses will be administered at the Osaka mass vaccination site beginning February 7. In Yokohama City, the municipal with the largest elderly population residing in the country, third dose vaccinations have already been underway and continues to be administered.    Schedule for third doses are as follows:  Feburary: 1.83 million medical workers and 11.6 million elderly people, 730,000 under 64 years old will be eligible.  March: 890,000 medical workers, 16.24 million elderly people, 64 years old or younger In addition to 4.35 million people, 1.68 million people who are "work-related inoculations" conducted at companies and universities are also eligible.  April: 3.13 million elderly people, 11.94 million people under 64 years old, 5 million occupational inoculations will be eligible.  May: 580,000 elderly people, 14.62 million people under 64 years old, 1.55 million occupational inoculations will be eligible.  June: 350,000 elderly people, 12.73 million under 64 years old, and 2.48 million occupational inoculations will be eligible and continue until September 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203031729/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211201/k10013369451000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235727/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220131/k10013457771000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235340/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220130/k10013457321000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235402/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220131/k10013458301000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235928/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220207/k10013470791000.html (Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235927/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220207/k10013471291000.html (Yokohama)

Third dose mass vaccination begins in Tokyo, starting with the elderly population. Yokohama City, who has already been administered third doses, continue to inoculate their population. Osaka will begin mass vaccination for third doses (beginning with the elderly) on February 7.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235727/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220131/k10013457771000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235340/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220130/k10013457321000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235402/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220131/k10013458301000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235928/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220207/k10013470791000.html (Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235927/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220207/k10013471291000.html (Yokohama)

From FB page of Office of Te Beretitenti (president)    "The Government has decided to extend the lockdown period on South Tarawa, Betio and Buota for 7 more days effective from 6am Friday 28 January 2022 to 6am Friday 4 February 2022. Furthermore, Te Beretitenti has also signed the extension of the Proclamation of a State Disaster to prepare for and manage the impact of novel corona virus 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic for another 30 days effective from Saturday 29 January 2022 to 28 February 2022, following the first proclamation made on 22 January 2022. "    "Noting that South Tarawa, Betio and Buota are still on alert level three, the following measures are still in effect:  Delivery of cargoes, fuels and medical supplies by vessel or air service will continue to the outer islands with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements. No travels between the outer islands are allowed.  1. Lock-down with 24 hours curfew.   2. All Government Offices and SOEs will be closed and work remotely from home, except for essential and emergency services.  â¢ Hospital services  â¢ Police services   â¢ Banking services  â¢ Kiribati Port Authority  â¢ Kiribati Oil Company and gas stations   â¢ Wholesalers and retailers selling food and essential items including Kiribati Copra Development Limited  â¢ Ministry of Finance and Economic Development   â¢ Ministry of Tourism, Commerce, Industry and Cooperatives   â¢ Telecommunication service providers   â¢ Public Broadcasting Authority   â¢ Public Utilities Board  â¢ Kiribati Meteorological Service  â¢ Ministry of Women, Youth, Sport and Social Affairs   â¢ Ministry of Information, Communication and Transport   â¢ Shipping and Aviation service providers  â¢ Kiribati Red Cross Society   â¢ Kiribati Family Health Association   â¢ Kiribati Fish Limited (KFL)   â¢ Central Pacific Producers Limited (CPPL)   3. And other essential services that the Government deems necessary during the lockdown.  These additional services require prior approval of Office of Te Beretitenti.    4. All essential service providers (food wholesale and retail) from the private sector will remain open to the public from 6am to 2pm.   5. People MUST stay at home â may only leave their homes for essential work or to access emergency services.   6. Access to shops for food shopping and other essential services will be zoned to limit the movement of people within their neighbourhoods or villages from 6am to 2pm. Movement to other villages requires prior approval of the Office of Te Beretitenti.   7. Fishing during shopping hours from 6am to 2pm is hereby allowed and that fishing boats or net fishing near shore is restricted to a group of 4 or a maximum of 4 crew for fishing boats. All fishing boats are not allowed to visit other villages or islands apart from their point of origin.  8. Public transportation services will cease during the lockdown.   9. All kava bars, liquor bars, and night clubs will be closed.  10. All kinds of social gatherings are banned.  11. Access to hospital services will be conducted according to the Ministry of Health and Medical Service guidelines as earlier announced.    12.  Delivery of cargoes, fuels and medical supplies by vessel or air service will continue to the outer islands with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements.   13.  No travels between the outer islands are allowed.  Update for Buota  The 10 days lockdown of Buota is now uplifted, however, peopleâs movement in and out of Buota will be restricted like the rest of South Tarawa.  This means that those wishing to enter or leave Buota for work or for other essential purposes will need to obtain a pass from the Office of Te Beretitenti (OB), similar with the movement of people between containment zones such as Betio to Bairiki.   In addition to the above, an EFTPOS machine will be made available in Buota for those needing to withdraw cash or for purchasing essential needs.   The public is advised to continue to strictly follow the Ministry of Health and Medical Services Standard Operational Procedures and comply with the curfew order to safeguard themselves and their families from this pandemic.  All requests for this weekend (Saturday 29th and Sunday 30th of January) passes are to reach the Office of the Beretitenti before 4pm on Friday 28th January 2022.  For Companies, Businesses, Ministries and Diplomatic Missions whose requests have been approved this week, these will be extended for the curfew period.    Government will continue to provide regular updates to the public for their information and safety."    http://archive.today/a205w

Lockdown orders for specific areas announced    https://www.president.gov.ki/images/Gazettes/2022/Order_STRW_English.pdf  https://www.president.gov.ki/images/Gazettes/2022/Lockdown_Order_OI_English.pdf

From FB page of Office of Te Beretitenti (date of post was 19/02/22 but post refers to policy measures introduced on 18/02/22)    Targeted measure: "8. School closure until the end of this month."    "Government has decided to further extend the lockdown period on the islands of North Tarawa, Maiana, Abaiang, Marakei and Abemama for another two more weeks or may be longer should the need arise and with different conditions due to the slow in spread of the diseases on these islands, effective from Friday 18th of February 2022. The islands of Aranuka and Makin who have just affected with the spread of COVID-19 will also be included among these islands.    Subsequent to the decision pertaining to this extension, there are also new decisions put in place in addition to the current measures under the Alert Level 3. These new measures which will only apply on North Tarawa, Maiana, Abaiang, Marakei and Abemama, including  Aranuka and Makin are as follows:  1. Curfew hours from 6pm to 6am everyday.   2. All Government Offices and SOES will be closed and work remotely from home, except for essential and emergency services which also follow the Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MHMS) guidelines:  ? Island Council Office  ? Hospital services  ? Police services  ? Kiribati Oil Company and gas stations  ? Wholesalers and retailers selling food  ? Telecommunication service providers  ? Kiribati Red Cross Society  ? Kiribati Family Health Association  3. And other essential that the Government and the Island Council deems necessary during the curfew. These additional services require prior approval of the Island Council Office.  4. All essential service providers (food wholesale and retail) from the private sector will remain open to the public from 6am to 6pm.  5. People MUST stay at home â may only leave their homes for essential work, or to access emergency services but must observe compulsory face mask, social distancing of 2 meters, not spitting and nose blowing in public places and other guidelines from the Ministry of Health and Medical Services (MHMS).  6. Access to shops for food shopping and other essential services will be zoned to limit the movement of people within their neighborhoods or villages from 6am to 6pm.  7. Public transportation services may operate but will also observe compulsory face mask, open windows, no spitting and nose blowing, and other MHMS guidelines and passengers must not share seats nor stand.  8. School closure until the end of this month.  9. All kava bars, liquor bars, and night clubs will be closed  10. Social gatherings (including Churches) up to 20 people are allowed to gather in outdoor setting. With appropriate distance, masks and good ventilation.  11. Access to hospital services will be conducted accordingly to the Ministry of Health and Medical Services guidelines as earlier announced.  12. Delivery of cargoes , fuels and medical supplies by vessels or air services will continue to outer island with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements.  13. No travels between the outer islands are allowed.  14. All police officers and other responsible Government officers are hereby ordered to ensure that this Order and future directions issued out of this Order and Public Health (Infectious Disease) Regulation and the Disaster Risk Management and Climate Change Act are complied with by the public.   15. Urgent direction(s) other than those listed here, if there is a need, may be issued later to the police and other officers of the Government for execution in relation to certain areas or groups of people or activities etc where it deemed necessary to achieve the purposes of this Order and the Public Health (Infectious Disease) Regulation and the Disaster Risk Management and Climate Change Act in relation to COVID-19.  16. Any person who contravenes any conditions of this Order commits an offence and will be liable to be arrested by the police or imprisonment. For clarification purposes, any breach of all the provisions of the Public Health (Infectious Disease) Regulation is an offence.  17. In case of any inconsistencies between this version and the Kiribati version, the Kiribati version shall prevail.  18. This Order repeals any previous Order and is effective on 18th February 2022 at 6 am until 4th March 2022 at 6am.  19. The non-affected islands with COVID-19 will continue their operations as usual.    Any person who contravenes any conditions of this Order commits an offence and will be liable to be arrested by the police or imprisonment. For clarification purposes, any breach of all the provisions of the Public Health (Infectious Disease) Regulation is an offence.   In case of any inconsistencies between this version and the Kiribati version, the Kiribati version shall prevail.    The public is advised to continue to strictly follow the Ministry of Health and Medical Services Standard Operational Procedures, comply with the curfew order, and to visit clinics for test if receiving symptoms to safeguard themselves and their families from this pandemic.    http://archive.today/7Q8G0

From FB page of Office of Te Beretitenti (president)    "The Government has decided to extend the lockdown period on South Tarawa, Betio and Buota for 7 more days effective from 6am Friday 28 January 2022 to 6am Friday 4 February 2022. Furthermore, Te Beretitenti has also signed the extension of the Proclamation of a State Disaster to prepare for and manage the impact of novel corona virus 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic for another 30 days effective from Saturday 29 January 2022 to 28 February 2022, following the first proclamation made on 22 January 2022. "    "Noting that South Tarawa, Betio and Buota are still on alert level three, the following measures are still in effect:  Delivery of cargoes, fuels and medical supplies by vessel or air service will continue to the outer islands with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements. No travels between the outer islands are allowed.  1. Lock-down with 24 hours curfew.   2. All Government Offices and SOEs will be closed and work remotely from home, except for essential and emergency services.  â¢ Hospital services  â¢ Police services   â¢ Banking services  â¢ Kiribati Port Authority  â¢ Kiribati Oil Company and gas stations   â¢ Wholesalers and retailers selling food and essential items including Kiribati Copra Development Limited  â¢ Ministry of Finance and Economic Development   â¢ Ministry of Tourism, Commerce, Industry and Cooperatives   â¢ Telecommunication service providers   â¢ Public Broadcasting Authority   â¢ Public Utilities Board  â¢ Kiribati Meteorological Service  â¢ Ministry of Women, Youth, Sport and Social Affairs   â¢ Ministry of Information, Communication and Transport   â¢ Shipping and Aviation service providers  â¢ Kiribati Red Cross Society   â¢ Kiribati Family Health Association   â¢ Kiribati Fish Limited (KFL)   â¢ Central Pacific Producers Limited (CPPL)   3. And other essential services that the Government deems necessary during the lockdown.  These additional services require prior approval of Office of Te Beretitenti.    4. All essential service providers (food wholesale and retail) from the private sector will remain open to the public from 6am to 2pm.   5. People MUST stay at home â may only leave their homes for essential work or to access emergency services.   6. Access to shops for food shopping and other essential services will be zoned to limit the movement of people within their neighbourhoods or villages from 6am to 2pm. Movement to other villages requires prior approval of the Office of Te Beretitenti.   7. Fishing during shopping hours from 6am to 2pm is hereby allowed and that fishing boats or net fishing near shore is restricted to a group of 4 or a maximum of 4 crew for fishing boats. All fishing boats are not allowed to visit other villages or islands apart from their point of origin.  8. Public transportation services will cease during the lockdown.   9. All kava bars, liquor bars, and night clubs will be closed.  10. All kinds of social gatherings are banned.  11. Access to hospital services will be conducted according to the Ministry of Health and Medical Service guidelines as earlier announced.    12.  Delivery of cargoes, fuels and medical supplies by vessel or air service will continue to the outer islands with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements.   13.  No travels between the outer islands are allowed.  Update for Buota  The 10 days lockdown of Buota is now uplifted, however, peopleâs movement in and out of Buota will be restricted like the rest of South Tarawa.  This means that those wishing to enter or leave Buota for work or for other essential purposes will need to obtain a pass from the Office of Te Beretitenti (OB), similar with the movement of people between containment zones such as Betio to Bairiki.   In addition to the above, an EFTPOS machine will be made available in Buota for those needing to withdraw cash or for purchasing essential needs.   The public is advised to continue to strictly follow the Ministry of Health and Medical Services Standard Operational Procedures and comply with the curfew order to safeguard themselves and their families from this pandemic.  All requests for this weekend (Saturday 29th and Sunday 30th of January) passes are to reach the Office of the Beretitenti before 4pm on Friday 28th January 2022.  For Companies, Businesses, Ministries and Diplomatic Missions whose requests have been approved this week, these will be extended for the curfew period.    Government will continue to provide regular updates to the public for their information and safety."    http://archive.today/a205w

All Government Offices and SOEs will be closed and work remotely from home, except for essential and emergency services.  â¢ Hospital services  â¢ Police services   â¢ Banking services  â¢ Kiribati Port Authority  â¢ Kiribati Oil Company and gas stations   â¢ Wholesalers and retailers selling food and essential items including Kiribati Copra Development Limited  â¢ Ministry of Finance and Economic Development   â¢ Ministry of Tourism, Commerce, Industry and Cooperatives   â¢ Telecommunication service providers   â¢ Public Broadcasting Authority   â¢ Public Utilities Board  â¢ Kiribati Meteorological Service  â¢ Ministry of Women, Youth, Sport and Social Affairs   â¢ Ministry of Information, Communication and Transport   â¢ Shipping and Aviation service providers  â¢ Kiribati Red Cross Society   â¢ Kiribati Family Health Association   â¢ Kiribati Fish Limited (KFL)   â¢ Central Pacific Producers Limited (CPPL)   3. And other essential services that the Government deems necessary during the lockdown.  These additional services require prior approval of Office of Te Beretitenti.    4. All essential service providers (food wholesale and retail) from the private sector will remain open to the public from 6am to 2pm.   5. People MUST stay at home â may only leave their homes for essential work or to access emergency services.   6. Access to shops for food shopping and other essential services will be zoned to limit the movement of people within their neighbourhoods or villages from 6am to 2pm. Movement to other villages requires prior approval of the Office of Te Beretitenti.   7. Fishing during shopping hours from 6am to 2pm is hereby allowed and that fishing boats or net fishing near shore is restricted to a group of 4 or a maximum of 4 crew for fishing boats. All fishing boats are not allowed to visit other villages or islands apart from their point of origin.  8. Public transportation services will cease during the lockdown.   9. All kava bars, liquor bars, and night clubs will be closed.  10. All kinds of social gatherings are banned.  11. Access to hospital services will be conducted according to the Ministry of Health and Medical Service guidelines as earlier announced.    12.  Delivery of cargoes, fuels and medical supplies by vessel or air service will continue to the outer islands with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements.   13.  No travels between the outer islands are allowed.  Update for Buota  The 10 days lockdown of Buota is now uplifted, however, peopleâs movement in and out of Buota will be restricted like the rest of South Tarawa.  This means that those wishing to enter or leave Buota for work or for other essential purposes will need to obtain a pass from the Office of Te Beretitenti (OB), similar with the movement of people between containment zones such as Betio to Bairiki.   In addition to the above, an EFTPOS machine will be made available in Buota for those needing to withdraw cash or for purchasing essential needs.   The public is advised to continue to strictly follow the Ministry of Health and Medical Services Standard Operational Procedures and comply with the curfew order to safeguard themselves and their families from this pandemic.  All requests for this weekend (Saturday 29th and Sunday 30th of January) passes are to reach the Office of the Beretitenti before 4pm on Friday 28th January 2022.  For Companies, Businesses, Ministries and Diplomatic Missions whose requests have been approved this week, these will be extended for the curfew period.    Government will continue to provide regular updates to the public for their information and safety."    http://archive.today/a205w

Any school that does not meet these criteria must take steps to do so and meet the conditions for reopening.    Schools that remain closed are advised to continue with online learning in key subjects    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214060253/http:/www.xinhuanet.com/english/asiapacific/20220203/1c2d4a0458924de4ad348d4c986f0866/c.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214004322/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/laos-officials-continue-to-enforce-covid-19-restrictions-as-of-feb-3-update-41

Many students in Laos have returned to classes despite the pandemic, with most being final-year students in primary and secondary schools.  The Ministry of Education and Sports says schools are ensuring that all teachers and students properly wear face masks, follow the rules on social distancing, wash their hands regularly, and keep classrooms well ventilated.  Any school that does not meet these criteria must take steps to do so and meet the conditions for reopening. Government continues to implement restrictions to curb the spread of COVID 19. Factories manufacturing products like consumer and pharmaceutical goods, shopping malls, retail establishments, and supermarkets can operate with restrictions, like opening hour limits. In provinces without community spread, eateries may provide dine-in services with at least a 1-meter (3-feet) distance between tables. Entertainment establishments, conferences of more than 50 people, and other types of gatherings are suspended.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214004322/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/laos-officials-continue-to-enforce-covid-19-restrictions-as-of-feb-3-update-41    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214054835/https:/www.covid19.gov.la/index.php?r=site%2Fdetail&id=960

The government continues to suspend tourist visas, visas on arrival, and standing visa exemptions from most international locations. Government agencies or other entities may apply for an entry approval for foreign essential workers, technical experts, and investors. International entrants must obtain prior permission from Laotian authorities at least seven days before arrival; provide a valid entry visa if applicable, a negative result from a PCR test taken within 72 hours before departure, and a completed health declaration form; and download the LaoKYC application. Foreign nationals must also have insurance coverage for COVID-19 treatment and other related expenses from international or local providers.    Authorities allow tourist arrivals from several locations in the first phase of international travel reopening through March 31. The locations include Australia, Austria, Belgium, Brunei, Cambodia, Canada, China, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Hungary, Indonesia, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Japan, Malaysia, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Philippines, Poland, Singapore, South Korea, Spain, Switzerland, the US, the UK, Thailand, and Vietnam. Travelers must be fully vaccinated at least 14 days before arrival, have a health insurance policy with a coverage of at least USD 50,000, obtain a negative PCR test result taken within 72 hours before departure, undergo an on-arrival PCR test, and remain at their accommodation until they receive a negative result from the on-arrival test.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214004322/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/laos-officials-continue-to-enforce-covid-19-restrictions-as-of-feb-3-update-41    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214054835/https:/www.covid19.gov.la/index.php?r=site%2Fdetail&id=960

International Travel Restrictions  The government continues to suspend tourist visas, visas on arrival, and standing visa exemptions from most international locations. Government agencies or other entities may apply for entry approval for foreign essential workers, technical experts, and investors. International entrants must obtain prior permission from Lao authorities at least seven days before arrival; provide a valid entry visa if applicable, a negative result from a PCR test taken within 72 hours before departure, and a completed health declaration form; and download the LaoKYC application. Foreign nationals must also have insurance coverage for COVID-19 treatment and other related expenses from international or local providers.    Authorities allow tourist arrivals from several locations in the first phase of Green Travel Zone international travel reopening scheme through March 31. The locations include Australia, Austria, Belgium, Brunei, Cambodia, Canada, China, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Hungary, Indonesia, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Japan, Malaysia, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Philippines, Poland, Singapore, South Korea, Spain, Switzerland, the US, the UK, Thailand, and Vietnam. Travelers must be fully vaccinated at least 14 days before arrival, have a health insurance policy with a coverage of at least USD 50,000, obtain a negative PCR test result taken within 72 hours before departure, undergo an on-arrival PCR test, and remain at their accommodation for 48 hours until they receive a negative result from the on-arrival test.    In the first phase of reopening, officials allow tourists to visit the Green Travel Zones of Vientiane Capital, Luang Prabang Province, and Vang Vieng District of Vientiane Province, as well as the Green Travel Trails of Champasack, Khammouane, Oudomxay, Xayaboury, and Xieng Khouang provinces. Green Travel Zones and Green Travel Trails are areas with vaccination rates of at least 70 percent and below 70 percent respectively. Authorities permit tourists to enter only through Wattay International Airport (VTE) and the First Lao-Thai Friendship Bridge in Vientiane Prefecture. Officials plan to categorize other localities, including Savannakhet Province, as Green Travel Zones and Green Travel Trails areas, and announce additional points of entry in the second phase of reopening from April 1-June 30.    Officials allow some border checkpoints, including those with Thailand, to open.
