With decreasing Covid-19 cases across Myanmar, public schools, private schools, and monastic education schools in all the townships except 46 in nine regions and states close to border areas were reopened starting on November 1.      http://web.archive.org/web/20220227142212/https://elevenmyanmar.com/news/yangon-schools-see-just-over-80000-of-over-500000-enrollees-on-reopening-day

COVID restrictions remain in place. Some restaurants have reopened but some are still closed or only offer to take away or deliver. Some shopping centers require customers to register their details upon entry. You must wear a face mask in all public places.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220227150719/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/myanmar/coronavirus

The military regime has instituted a ban on gatherings of five or more people, and a nationwide curfew from 8:00 P.M. until 4:00 A.M.  In Rangoon, the curfew was shortened to 10:00 P.M. to 4:00 A.M.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220227143450/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The military regime has instituted a ban on gatherings of five or more people, and a nationwide curfew from 8:00 P.M. until 4:00 A.M.  In Rangoon, the curfew was shortened to 10:00 P.M. to 4:00 A.M.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220227143450/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Trains: A limited number of train routes are operating.  Buses: Intra-provincial bus service has resumed but may be limited due to COVID-19 travel restrictions. City buses are limited due to the ongoing civil unrest.     http://web.archive.org/web/20220227143450/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

During COVID-19 stay-at-home orders in Burma, residents may only leave their residence to travel to/from work, to buy groceries, or for medical treatment.  A mask must be worn at all times when outside the home.  Authorities set up checkpoints in Rangoon and elsewhere to verify travelers are on the road for permitted reasons.     http://web.archive.org/web/20220227143450/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Some domestic flights have resumed in Burma. On December 5, 2021, the regime Ministry of Transport and Communications canceled domestic flight operations from Kalay Township, Chin State due to its proximity to India where the new Omicron variant has been detected.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220227143450/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Burmese authorities will no longer allow international commercial passenger flights to land at any airport in Burma.  This suspension will last until further notice.  All landing permissions previously granted are suspended.  Exceptions apply to ârelief flights, all-cargo flights, medical evacuation flights and special flights specifically approved by the Department of Civil Aviation.â All foreign nationals, including U.S. citizens and all diplomats and U.N. officials, are required to present laboratory evidence of absence of COVID-19 infection issued no more than 72 hours prior to the date of travel before boarding any airline destined to Burma. U.S. citizens have reported being asked to submit to a COVID-19 health examination as part of their in-country Burmese visa renewal process.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220227143450/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Household support- In-kind and cash transfers to the most vulnerable population (MMK 404billion)through Apr-Sep and 4 round cash transfer (MMK 164 billion) in Nov-Dec. Transferring MMK 400 billion to Myanmar Economic Bank to establish a COVID 19 Fund to provide soft loans to affected businesses (particularly the priority garment and tourism sectors and SMEs) at 1 percent interest for one year. The repayment term was extended by six months; (ii) provision of MMK 600 billion loans to farmers.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220227151645/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Authorities have authorized COVID-19 vaccinations for use in Burma, including the CoronaVac, AstraZeneca, CoviShield, Pfizer BioNTech, Comirnaty, Janssen/Johnson&Johnson, Moderna, Sinopharm, Sputnik, and Covaxin vaccines. These vaccines are given to Key workers, Clinically vulnerable groups, and Elderly groups.     http://web.archive.org/web/20220227153955/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Myanmar government established the COVID-19 Vaccination Fund to procure vaccines. A total of 24 target groups has been designated and prioritized for the COVID-19 vaccination program including different age groups of people, health staff, inmates from jails and custody, persons with disabilities, members and families of ethnic armed organizations, people in IDP camps, and students (12-18 years old).    http://web.archive.org/web/20220227161124/https://mohs.gov.mm/ckfinder/connector?command=Proxy&lang=en&type=MainÂ¤tFolder=%2FNews%2FNews_2021%2FOct_2021%28A%29%2F&hash=a6a1c319429b7abc0a8e21dc137ab33930842cf5&fileName=GAVI+COVAX+Facility+MoH+English+%285-10-2021%29.pdf

A total of 24 target groups has been designated and prioritized for the COVID-19 vaccination program including different age groups of people, health staff, inmates from jails and custody, persons with disabilities, members and families of ethnic armed organizations, people in IDP camps, and students (12-18 years old). All the vaccination activities are recorded and reported in the Vaccine Management Information System-VMIS. Therefore, the COVID-19 vaccination program in Myanmar is currently active for 24 groups and is in a neutral manner without any discrimination, leaving no one behind irrespective of their ethnicity, religion, gender, socio-economic status, or political affiliation.     http://web.archive.org/web/20220227161124/https://mohs.gov.mm/ckfinder/connector?command=Proxy&lang=en&type=Main&currentFolder=%2FNews%2FNews_2021%2FOct_2021%28A%29%2F&hash=a6a1c319429b7abc0a8e21dc137ab33930842cf5&fileName=GAVI+COVAX+Facility+MoH+English+%285-10-2021%29.pdf

Two states are in Phase 3, Sarawak and Kelantan. Others are in Phase 4. For Phase 3 states, "All educational institutions are reopened; institutions under the Ministry of Education will open by stages, subject to risk assessments and the Ministry of Education. Face-to-face learning activities are allowed; face-to-face learning activities by higher education institutions are subject to 70% student capacity limits and SOP". For Phase 4 states, "All educational institutions are reopened, subject to current risk assessment".    Vaccination is mandatory for university students to go to campus, but not for other levels.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211111654/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/kelantan/dashboard-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222070347/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/laporan/PPN-en/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222072025/https://www.malaymail.com/news/malaysia/2022/02/07/covid-19-school-closures-will-affect-students-personality-intellectual-deve/2040078    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222071101/https://www.malaymail.com/news/malaysia/2021/09/12/minister-only-fully-vaccinated-students-can-return-to-campus/2004876  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222071136/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/malaysia-starts-vaccinating-5-to-11-year-old-kids-amid-worries-over-school-clusters

Fully vaccinated individuals are permitted to enter Langkawi Island as a tourist under the international tourism bubble.     For fully vaccinated individuals, quarantine for 7 days on arrival in Malaysia, reduced to 5 days if one has received a vaccine booster. Citizens and non-citizens who have a residence in Malaysia and arrived from abroad, may have their compulsory quarantine at home.    Non-fully vaccinated individuals must quarantine in a designated quarantine centre for 10 days.     https://archive.vn/jbj8L  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

PSU is a financial assistance paid to the employer of each enterprise for each local employee.  It is targeted towards employers operating in the tourism sector, who experienced a decrease in income of at least 30% of total sales or income. It is a wage subsidy of RM600 (USD $143) per month for each employee, for 3 months. It is limited to 500 employees per claim.    https://archive.vn/QZHmW

Bank Negara Malaysia (Central Bank of Malaysia) provides loan repayment assistance:  Moratorium for 6 months.  No supporting documentation required.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211226111954/https://www.bnm.gov.my/RA
The government has a dedicated website for COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102417/https://covid--19-moh-gov-my.translate.goog/?_x_tr_sl=ms&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=nui%2Csc

The use of the MySejethera app is not mandated but generally used across Malaysia for many functions including booking vaccinations and tracking social movements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211226113805/https://mysejahtera.malaysia.gov.my/intro_en/
Facial coverings are required in Malaysia.    https://archive.vn/jbj8L

Vaccinations are freely available and fully funded by the government for all citizens and foreign residents. Walk-in booster vaccinations for adults 18 years and above opened nationwide on January 29, 2022.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220222083033/https://my.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
No specific information on elderly.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222065648/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html

Both citizens and foreigners receive free vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222083033/https://my.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

New Zealand is now at Red traffic light setting under the COVID-19 Protection Framework (CPF). Schools and kura are open for on site learning, for all students. Schools are prohibited from requiring students to be vaccinated to access education. This includes parents, caregivers and whanau supporting students and their learning. Physical distancing and mask-wearing are in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220215070204/https://www.education.govt.nz/covid-19/advice-for-schoolskura/covid-19-protection-framework-advice-for-schools-and-kura/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220215070212/https://www.education.govt.nz/covid-19/advice-for-schoolskura/covid-19-protection-framework-advice-for-schools-and-kura/red/

Workplaces can open at Red. One can work from home if it is appropriate for their job. Some workplaces may be covered by vaccine mandates. This means workers in businesses covered by the mandate must be vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220203215133/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/businesses-and-workplaces-at-red/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214123220/https://www.health.govt.nz/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-response-planning/covid-19-mandatory-vaccinations

Controlled-access events involve ticketing, registration or another way to control access. There can be up to 100 people in a defined space at the venue at any time, based on 1-metre physical distancing. This includes children, but not workers.    Outdoor community gatherings can go ahead but must follow the gathering guidelines. They are gatherings that are open to the public and do not require tickets or registration.    Events cannot go ahead if My Vaccine Pass requirements are not followed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220215072048/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/events-and-public-facilities-at-red/events-at-red/

Events are limited to 100 people if everyone has a My Vaccine Pass. Children and babies are included in the event limits â but not people working at events. When food and drink is being served, you must be seated and separated. Face masks should be worn at an event. Events staff and volunteers must wear a face covering.    Events cannot go ahead if My Vaccine Pass requirements are not followed.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220215072048/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/events-and-public-facilities-at-red/events-at-red/

You do not need to show a vaccine pass to use public transport, as these services are needed to access services for basic needs such as food and healthcare.    There are no physical distancing requirements on public transport, at bus stops or train stations.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220123080144/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/travel-and-accommodation-at-red/travel-at-red/
No policy change.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108150854/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/

One can travel anywhere in New Zealand at all traffic light settings. There are no boundaries under the traffic lights. Do not travel if one is unwell, isolating or waiting for the results of a COVID-19 test. Unless the transport provider requires it, one does not need a My Vaccine Pass or a negative COVID-19 test to travel.     Free rapid antigen tests (RATs) are available at selected community pharmacies until 30 June 2022. The tests are available for travellers from any part of New Zealand who: are not fully vaccinated, and are over the age of 12 years and 3 months, and do not have COVID-19 symptoms, and need a negative test result to travel with a transport company.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220203003712mp_/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/travel-and-accommodation-at-red/travel-at-red/

No policy change at the moment. New Zealand is now at Red traffic light setting under the COVID-19 Protection Framework (CPF). One must wear a face mask on flights, public transport, and taxis, in retail shops and public venues, and in health and education facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220208033816/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/

Everyone in Aotearoa New Zealand aged 5 years and over is eligible for free COVID-19 vaccination. Those over 18 who are fully vaccinated can also book their free booster. It doesnât matter what one's visa or citizenship status is.    Pfizer is the preferred COVID-19 vaccine for use in New Zealand.  If one is 18 years of age or older and either you cannot get the Pfizer vaccine or one wants a different option, they can get the AstraZeneca vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214093208/https://www.health.govt.nz/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-vaccines

One can visit friends and whanau in a rest home or aged care facility, but there may be restrictions. Some facilities may only allow fully vaccinated people to visit. One must wear a face mask when visiting an aged care facility. Do not visit an aged care facility or rest home if one is unwell, have symptoms of COVID-19, is self-isolating or is waiting for the results of a COVID-19 test.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220108162633/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/gatherings-and-visits-at-red/visiting-friends-and-whanau-at-red    https://web.archive.org/web/20220215080018/https://www.health.govt.nz/covid-19-novel-coronavirus/covid-19-information-health-professionals/covid-19-aged-care-disability-and-hospice-care-providers/covid-19-aged-care-providers

As of February 10, 2022, the Philippines will grant entry to fully vaccinated visitors from countries that are permitted visa-free travel, including the United States.  Fully vaccinated travelers will no longer be subject to facility-based quarantine upon arrival.  Travelers must present proof of vaccination and negative RT-PCR results from a test taken within 48 hours of departure from their country of origin and must self-monitor for symptoms for seven days after arrival, reporting to local government authorities if they begin to exhibit COVID-19 symptoms.  The same requirements apply to fully vaccinated travelers with valid, existing visas.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220214083301/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
All schools reopened on Jan 31 after Dec break. There is no news of any school closures or restrictions.

An official national curfew not currently in place, but business operations may be limited to prescribed hours. Fully vaccinated travellers may travel within Papua New Guinea without restrictions except to/from high-risk areas. Effective October 13, 2021, the NCC has designated Western, Sandaun (West Sepik), Eastern Highlands, Western Highlands, Morobe, Chimbu, Enga, Hela, Jiwaka, and Southern as âhigh-riskâ provinces, and will implement restrictions on public or religious gatherings, public venues, and domestic passenger movements on aircraft into/within/from these provinces.  The only pre-approved travel into/within/from âhigh-riskâ provinces will be for health workers, business travel, and students.     Unvaccinated travellers must have one of the following valid purposes of travel:        Students returning to their usual place of residence or returning to their educational institutions;      Return to a habitual place of residence;      Essential business travel;      Medical assistance, emergencies, or medivac;      Emergency transport, including but not limited to repatriation of deceased persons;      Persons who have approval from the Controller, the Controllerâs delegate, or the provincial administrator from the travelerâs province of origin. Travellers should consult with their respective airline(s) prior to travel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220120182508/https:/pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of Feb 16, government has eased restrictions on domestic travel.    Regarding domestic travel restrictions, officials prohibit symptomatic people from boarding flights; authorities are checking the temperatures of passengers before flights and ban travel for people whose temperatures are 37.5C (99.5F) or higher. Travelers must complete and submit a National Department of Health form to the Provincial Health Authority upon arrival.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220234935/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-ease-covid-19-travel-restrictions-as-of-feb-16-some-domestic-measures-continuing-update-46    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221000020/https:/postcourier.com.pg/covid-19-restrictions-no-longer-apply-on-public-transport/

Fully vaccinated citizens, permanent residents, and foreign nationals can enter the country with written approval from the National Pandemic Controller's Office; tourist travel remains banned.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205205616/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-adjust-covid-19-entry-restrictions-nationwide-tighter-domestic-measures-continue-through-feb-28-update-45    https://web.archive.org/web/20220120182508/https:/pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Papua New Guinea authorities have reopened borders to tourists as of Feb. 16. Officials have also lifted requirements for arrivals to have written permission from the National Pandemic Controller's Office to enter. All arrivals must be fully vaccinated, though Papua New Guinea citizens and travelers under 18 years old are exempted. Entrants must also provide a negative COVID-19 test obtained within 72 hours before departure and undergo a COVID-19 test upon arrival. Individuals who tested positive in the last three months must provide a medical certificate indicating the person is no longer infectious. Authorities are not enforcing mandatory quarantine for most arrivals; people who test positive when tested on arrival must quarantine for seven days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220234935/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-ease-covid-19-travel-restrictions-as-of-feb-16-some-domestic-measures-continuing-update-46    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221000020/https:/postcourier.com.pg/covid-19-restrictions-no-longer-apply-on-public-transport/

no coding changes to the period of 12-22 February 2022.    Vaccine differentiated measures have not imposed in schools.  Covid safety measures are currently still enforced in educational institutions.  _________________________    Quote (1):  "Will Vaccination Differentiated Safe Management Measures (VDS) be introduced in schools and IHLs?  There are presently no plans to introduce VDS in our pre-schools, primary schools or SPED schools with primary/junior section. Our priority now is to ensure our children are well protected against COVID-19 as we begin vaccination for those aged five to 11 years.    Similarly, COVID-19 vaccination is not a requirement for physical attendance in our secondary schools, SPED schools with secondary/senior sections, junior colleges and Millennia Institute. Access to quality education remains MOEâs priority. However, where there are public health reasons to better protect our students participating in higher risk activities, additional measures would be put in place. For example, unvaccinated students are required to perform a self-administered Antigen Rapid Test (ART) prior to participating in higher-risk activities such as singing and playing wind instruments. In addition, under the ongoing MCCY-MOE Team Sports Pilot for schools and IHLs, only fully vaccinated students who have taken an on-site ART self-swab are allowed to participate in team sports in groups of up to 10.    From 1 February 2022, VDS will be expanded to include Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs). For now, VDS will only apply to all visitors who enter the IHLs. (IHL staff are already subject to VDS via MOMâs Workforce Vaccination Measures.) All students will be exempted from VDS. This exemption is subject to review.    To facilitate the safe resumption of in-person activities for IHL students, all unvaccinated students will be required to complete a weekly self-administered Antigen Rapid Test (ART) regime to take part in higher risk activities on campus which require VDS, such as indoor unmasked activities or large-scale student events.    All staff in schools or IHLs are to adhere to the Workforce Vaccination Measures put in place by MOM."      "What are the arrangements for Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) for the resumption of term in 2022?  The Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) have increased the number of students allowed back on campus at any one time for face-to-face learning.    More student activities and large scale student events will resume in line with national guidelines on group sizes and event sizes."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220222054820/https://www.moe.gov.sg/faqs-covid-19-infection

No Coding changes for the period of 29 January to 07 February 2022.  _____________________________________  ***Please refer to notes dated 28 January 2022:    From 15 January 2022 onwards, a vaccine mandate for workers is implemented in order to be able to return to work places. Negative tests are no longer accepted for those unvaccinated.  A grace period for partially vaccinated individuals is in place until 31 January 2022.    50% of employees are now allowed back to the workplaces at any given point in time; although, they must adhere to the vaccine mandate as afore mentioned.  ____________    Quote (1):  "Phase 2 (15 January 2022 onwards): Only employees who are fully vaccinated, certified to be medically ineligible or have recovered from COVID-19 within 180 days, can return to the workplace. The concession for unvaccinated employees to perform PET in lieu of being fully vaccinated will be removed, i.e. such employees will not be allowed to return to the workplace even if they did PET with a negative result. Partially vaccinated7 employees will still be allowed at workplaces with a negative PET result up to 31 January 2022 after which they must be fully vaccinated."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128135348/https://www.mom.gov.sg/covid-19/advisory-on-covid-19-vaccination-in-employment-settings  ___________    Quote (2):  "The following measures are put in place to slow the rate of transmission and minimise strain on our healthcare capacity.  From 1 January 2022, more employees3 are allowed to return to the workplace.  Up to 50% of employees who are able to work from home can be at the workplace at any point in time. For example, a company with 100 employees who can work from home can have up to 50 of these employees at the workplace at any point in time."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220103082447/https://www.mom.gov.sg/covid-19/requirements-for-safe-management-measures

No Coding changes for the period of 29 January to 07 February 2022.  _____________________________________  ***Please refer to notes dated 28 January 2022:    Vaccine differentiated measures are currently in place with only vaccinated individuals allowed into events. Current Covid safety measurements still prevail in all settings.  _________________    Quote (1):  " From 1 January 2022, the concession for unvaccinated individuals to perform PET in lieu of being fully vaccinated will be removed. Only fully vaccinated, recovered, or medically ineligible individuals, or children aged 12 years and below (subject to venue/event specific caps) will be allowed to enter settings where VDS is implemented."    "ATTRACTIONS,SHOWS & CRUISES  Entry allowed only if vaccinated.    CONGREGATIONAL & WORSHIP SERVICES  All vaccinated^ : Up to 1,000 worshippers.  Vaccinated performers or speakers may be unmasked, including for singing or playing of wind instruments at live performances.    MARRIAGE SOLEMNISATIONS  All vaccinated^ : Up to 1,000 attendees.    MUSEUMS & PUBLIC LIBRARIES  Entry allowed only if vaccinated."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128150314/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19-phase-advisory  __________________    Quote (2):  "(D) Expanding VDS to More Venues    10. Vaccination is key to protecting our population even as SMMs are further relaxed. From 1 December 2021, we will expand VDS to more settings and activities, including in all Libraries under the National Library Board (NLB), and selected activities in community clubs/centres under Peopleâs Association (PA). By restricting entry to only individuals who have been fully vaccinated, we can further reduce the risk of transmission in such settings.     11. A summary of the updated community measures from 22 November 2021 can be found in Annex A.     (E) Removal of VDS Concession for Voluntarily Unvaccinated Individuals     12. We will further strengthen efforts to protect unvaccinated individuals from getting infected, as they are subject to greater risks of severe illness. Under current rules, unvaccinated individuals can get a PET and show a negative test result to enter a VDS setting. We will remove this concession for unvaccinated individuals to perform PET in lieu of being fully vaccinated.  Hence, only fully vaccinated, recovered, or medically ineligible individuals, or children aged 12 years and below (subject to venue/event-specific caps) will be allowed to enter settings where VDS is implemented. We will effect this on 1 January 2022, to allow time for more individuals to complete their primary series vaccination regime. "    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220116160914/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/resuming-our-transition-towards-covid-resilience

no coding changes for the period of 12-22 February 2022.  Although there have been some adjustments to covid measures, there are still some specific restrictions depending on the type and capacity of the event.  ____________    Quote (1):    "Capacity Limits    From 4 March 2022, specific event size limits for events such as religious services, business events, media conferences, funerary memorial events, wedding receptions, and mask-on classes1, will be lifted. Zoning requirements will also be removed.    However, for large events and settings which pose more infection risks, capacity limits will be imposed as a precaution. These will include attractions, cruises, MICE and large work-related events, as well as large performing arts venues or sports stadiums. For other settings such as shopping malls and large standalone stores, the current density limit of 10sqm/pax roughly translates to 50% capacity too. For now, we will set the threshold at 1,000 pax."    Link (1):  http://web.archive.org/web/20220222054302/https://www.gov.sg/article/revised-safe-management-measures-from-25-february-2022

Link [1]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030005/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/current-covid-19-rules-will-stay-during-cny-period-in-view-of-omicron-wave-lawrence-wong  Link [2]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030048/https://www.todayonline.com/singapore/no-plans-relax-covid-19-curbs-chinese-new-year-holidays-lawrence-wong-1784181  Link [3]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030109/https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/government-economy/we-dont-intend-to-relax-further-says-lawrence-wong-as-covid-curbs-look-set-to  Link [4]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030130/https://www.gov.sg/article/safe-management-measures-and-chinese-new-year  ____________________  *** Please refer to previous notes:    No Coding Changes to the period of 01-06 January 2022. Recent updates from the government states that in light of the Omicron variant, the current Covid-19 safety measurements will remain unchanged right into the Chinese New Year (CNY) period - this commences on the 01-02 February 2022 and normally the period stretches for 14 days.  ________________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore's current set of Covid-19 safe management rules will stay in place during the upcoming Chinese New Year period from Feb 1, in view of a likely surge of infections brought about by the new Omicron variant, said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong on Wednesday (Jan 5). Group sizes for gathering and dining at restaurants have been capped at five since November, when Singapore emerged from an outbreak caused by the earlier Delta variant. Mr Wong, who is a co-chair of the multi-ministry task force handling Covid-19, said during a press conference that the present posture would be maintained as he could not imagine the Omicron wave passing before Chinese New Year."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220106084209/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/current-covid-19-rules-will-stay-during-cny-period-in-view-of-omicron-wave-lawrence-wong.    ______________________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 18 Dec 2021:  No Coding changes to the period of 14-18 Dec.   _____________  ***Please refer to notes dated 19 Nov 2021:    No coding changes for the period of 07-19 Nov 2021 [Link (1)]. Covid safety measures in place but no reduction to services country-wide [Link(1)]. Ridership rates have been on the rise and more hopes that might return to pre-pandemic levels. not restrictions in services seen.  ____________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - Public transport ridership recovered in 2021 on the back of relaxed Covid-19 restrictions, but the numbers are still the second lowest since 2010.  Bus and train rides averaged 5.259 million a day in 2021 - 4.3 per cent higher than in 2020, based on figures released by the Land Transport Authority on Monday (Feb 21)."    "More people are expected to return to taking public transport as the economy reopens further this year.  Last month, bus and rail rides averaged 5.785 million a day - a 10 per cent jump from the 2021 average.  But observers reckon that it would take some time to go back to the all-time ridership high of 7.691 million seen before the Covid-19 pandemic in 2019."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220222053312/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/transport/bus-train-rides-rise-but-numbers-still-far-from-pre-covid-19-levels

No Coding changes for the period of 29 January to 07 February 2022.  _____________________________________  ***Please refer to notes dated 28 January 2022:    Vaccine differentiated measures for travelers to Singapore have been in place for many months and have recently increased to include a mandate for work passes. There are a few exceptions but these might require pre-approval but a government body.  _______________________    Quote (1):  "Persons who are medically unfit to be vaccinated are not allowed to travel under the VTL (Air).  Unvaccinated short-term visitors will not be allowed to travel to Singapore.    However, unvaccinated:  Singapore Citizens  Permanent Residents, and  Long-Term Pass holders who have received entry approval via the SC/PR Familial Ties Lane  may still travel to Singapore on a non-designated flight. They will be subject to the prevailing Stay-Home Notice (SHN) and COVID-19 test requirements upon entry into Singapore.    3. What must travellers present as their proof of vaccination at check-in and arrival immigration?  I am a...	My proof of vaccination was issued...	I will need to present...  Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident	In Singapore	Either a valid vaccination status on the TraceTogether or HealthHub app or a vaccination certificate issued by the Singapore Ministry of Health.  Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident	Overseas	One of the accepted proof of vaccination, which may include your overseas-issued vaccination certificate  Long-Term Pass Holder or Short-Term Visitor	In Singapore	A valid Vaccinated Travel Pass (Air) [VTP (Air)], which you can apply for here*. Please click here for more details.  Long-Term Pass Holder or Short-Term Visitor	Overseas	  A valid Vaccinated Travel Pass (Air) [VTP (Air)], which you can apply for here*, and an accepted proof of vaccination, if necessary.    *On the VTP (Air) application portal, please select one of the following options depending on your pass type:  MOM Long-Term Pass Holder if you are a holder of an Employment Pass, Work Pass, Dependentâs Pass, MOM Long-Term Visit Pass, etc.; or  MOE Long-Term Pass Holder if you are a Student Pass holder."    Link (1): http://archive.today/2022.01.28-152708/https://safetravel.ica.gov.sg/vtl/faq  _____________________    Quote (2):  "Covid Vaccination Mandatory In Singapore From February 2022  Singapore: Singapore has made Covid vaccination a mandatory condition for the approval of new applications for work passes, long-term passes and permanent residence in Singapore from February 1 next year. Those renewing their work passes will also have to be vaccinated, The Straits Times reported, citing the multi-ministry task force (MMTF) on Covid."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128152404/https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/coronavirus-covid-vaccination-mandatory-in-singapore-from-february-2022-2673179  ____________________    Quote (3):  "Calibrating Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) Testing Regimes    24.    On 31 December 2021, we announced a four-week extension to the enhanced 7- day testing regime for travellers arriving via VTLs in order to facilitate the detection of imported Omicron cases and slow transmission into the community. This has bought time for us to booster vaccinate more residents, learn more about the Omicron variant and make necessary adjustments to our COVID-19 strategy. As imported cases now form a shrinking proportion of our overall cases, we will simplify the VTL testing regime.    25.     These measures are less relevant now. Hence, VTL travellers entering Singapore after 23 January 2022, 2359 hours via both air and land checkpoints will only be required to do unsupervised self-administered ARTs from Day 2 to Day 7 of their arrivals if they need to leave their place of residence or accommodation. Travellers need not submit their ART results but must test negative before going out. VTL travellers who arrive before 23 January 2022, 2359 hours are still required to continue with the existing testing regime (i.e. unsupervised self-administered ART on Days 2, 4, 5 and 6 with submission of results online, and supervised ART on Days 3 and 7 from their arrival).    26.    Travellers who test positive on ARTs (i.e. the on-arrival test for VTL-Land and unsupervised self-administered ARTs on Days 2 to 7) no longer need to undergo a confirmatory PCR test, but should instead simply recover under Protocol 2.2 That said, those who identify themselves as potentially at risk (as stipulated in Annex C) should visit a doctor for medical advice after testing positive even if they feel well.    27.     We will continue to maintain a 50% limit on VTL flight and bus tickets for entry into Singapore for now. We will continue to review the local and global COVID-19 situation and adjust our measures accordingly.    Facilitating Travel for Recently-Recovered Travellers    28.    With the growing number of cases worldwide, there is a rise in the number of travellers who have recently recovered from COVID-19. Such travellers can continue to shed non-infectious viral fragments even after they have recovered, and therefore test positive for COVID-19 despite posing no infection risk. As fully vaccinated individuals who recently recovered from infection have a high level of immunity through their recent COVID-19 infection and vaccination, the likelihood of reinfection is low.    29.     Hence, travellers arriving after 23 January 2022, 2359 hours who are fully vaccinated and recently recovered (i.e. within 90 days of their last infection) will be exempted from all testing and SHN requirements if they are able to provide appropriate documentary proof. Non-fully vaccinated recently-recovered travellers will be exempted from pre-departure testing requirements, but will still be subjected to all other prevailing border measures. This will facilitate the safe return of recently-recovered residents who travel overseas. See Annex D for the list of documentation to be presented by such travellers at check-in and arrival immigration to qualify for this exemption."    Link (3): http://archive.today/2022.01.28-152933/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/focusing-our-resources-and-refining-our-healthcare-protocols-to-deal-with-the-omicron-wave

Only Vaccinated individuals are allowed to travel to Singapore via designated Vaccinated Travel Lanes. Travel restrictions for these individuals  have been recently amended such that quarantine and PCR testing has been lifted with only ARTs required (Antigen Rapid tests). Prevailing guidelines remain for those who test positive on arrival.  __________________________    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220222055554/https://www.caas.gov.sg/who-we-are/newsroom/Detail/singapore-restores-and-extends-vaccinated-travel-lane  Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220221093802/https://www.mpa.gov.sg/web/portal/home/media-centre/news-releases/detail/342248ef-60a8-460e-ba01-d243379e119b  Link (3): http://web.archive.org/web/20220126210050/https://safetravel.ica.gov.sg/news-and-media/  Link (4): http://archive.today/2022.02.22-060211/https://www.mti.gov.sg/Newsroom/Press-Releases/2022/02/Restoring-of-Quotas-and-Streamlining-of-Border-Measures-for-VTL-Land

In additon, the government announced SGD$130 million (Approx USD$ 95 million) stimuli in the form of cash vouchers that can be utilized at select merchants across the country,    ___________________  Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - All Singaporean households can now collect $100 worth of vouchers that they can spend at about 10,000 participating hawkers and heartland merchants.    The community development council (CDC) vouchers, worth $130 million in total and given out to 1.3 million households, are available for collection digitally from Monday (Dec 13) and can be used till Dec 31, 2022."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20211213094222/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/100-worth-of-cdc-vouchers-for-each-sporean-household-available-for-collection-online  ________________    Quote (2): [Exchange Rate]  "Dec 13, 2021 09:38 UTC  Singapore Dollar	130,000,000.00 SGD	  US Dollar	95035922.924214	@ 1.367904"    Link (2): https://web.archive.org/web/20211213094242/https://www.x-rates.com/historical/?from=SGD&amount=130000000&date=2021-12-13  ______________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 19 Nov 2021:    No coding changes for the period of 07-19 Nov 2021.     ____________________________________  ****Please refer to previous notes dated 6 Nov 2021:    no coding changes to the period of 02-06 Nov 2021.   ___________________  ***Please refer to notes dates 01 Nov 2021:    No coding changes for the period of 24 Oct -01 Nov.  ___________________  *** Please refer to notes dates 23 Oct 2021    Support to continue until Nov 21 in light of the further extensions of the current restrictions.  ___________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE: A S$640 million support package will be rolled out for affected businesses and workers, after it was announced on Wednesday (Oct 20) that Singapore will extend its COVID-19 restrictions by nearly a month.  The stabilisation phase, which started on Sep 27 to help reduce the strain on the healthcare system, was scheduled to last until Oct 24.   It has now been extended until Nov 21, with a review of the measures at the two-week mark. They may be adjusted based on the situation then, said the Ministry of Health (MOH) in a media release.  During the stabilisation phase, social gatherings and dining-in have been capped at groups of two, while work-from-home has been the default arrangement.  Given the extended restrictions, the Government will continue with the Jobs Support Scheme until Nov 21, at 25 per cent wage support for sectors significantly affected by the tightened measures.  These include F&B, retail, cinemas, museums and art galleries, family entertainment, tourism, gyms and fitness studios, as well as performing arts and arts education.  A two-week rental waiver will be given to qualifying tenants on government-owned commercial properties.  Eligible tenant-occupiers and owner-occupiers of privately-owned commercial properties will also be given a 0.5-month rental relief cash payout under the Rental Support Scheme (RSS).  Cooked food and market stallholders in centres managed by the National Environment Agency (NEA) or operators appointed by NEA will receive a 0.5-month rental waiver.    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20211023041636/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid-19-support-package-jobs-support-scheme-extended-restrictions-2257036

No coding changes for the period of 12-22 Feb 2022.  _______________________    Quote (1):  "About Combined Test Centres (CTCs)  Combined Test Centres (CTCs), previously known as Regional Screening Centres (RSCs), are set up around Singapore to carry out COVID-19 swab tests for target groups from the general community who are well or have been diagnosed with acute respiratory infection. CTCs provide both the self-paid Antigen Rapid Test (ART) and the COVID-19 Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) swab test.    Click here for the locations of CTCs.  About Quick Test Centres (QTCs)  Quick Test Centres (QTCs) provide self-paid ART, where the test will be self-administered and supervised by an approved COVID-19 test provider. The test will cost $15 (inclusive of GST), with payment to be made at the QTCs through cashless modes, such as Mastercard, NETS, PayNow and Visa. Individuals will need to bring along their photo identification for verification at the QTC.    Both the CTCs and QTCs are important as they support COVID-19 testing, which helps to keep our homes and communities safe, especially as we re-open and resume our activities.    Click here for the locations of QTCs CTCs."    "Expanded Venues for COVID-19 Testing for Symptomatic Individuals  Members of the public who are experiencing acute respiratory symptoms (e.g. fever, cough, flu or runny nose), and are unable to secure an appointment at any of the Swab and Send Home (SASH) clinics during the weekend and public holidays, may book an appointment here, at one of our Combined Testing Centres (CTCs) to get a government-funded ART and confirmatory PCR test.    For the locations of CTCs, click here.  Self-Paid Antigen Rapid Test for Pre-Event Testing  From 1 October 2021, individuals aged 3 years and above, who need a valid negative COVID-19 ART result for entry into venues that require a negative Pre-Event or Pre-Visit Test may book an appointment at any of the QTCs for a self-paid ART. Minors aged 3 to 12, must be accompanied by a caregiver, aged 21 years old and above. The caregiver may be required to help administer the test if the minor is unable to do so. The results, which are valid for 24 hours, may be used to meet requirements such as those for pre-event test or pre-visit test.     Individuals are required to book an appointment at any of the following testing venues, prior to the visit."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220222052846/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/quick-test-centres-%28qtcs%29

No coding changes for the period of 07-17 January 2022.  All restrictions will remain the same all the way to and during the Chinese New Year (CNY) period in Early to mid February 2022.    Link [1]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030005/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/current-covid-19-rules-will-stay-during-cny-period-in-view-of-omicron-wave-lawrence-wong  Link [2]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030048/https://www.todayonline.com/singapore/no-plans-relax-covid-19-curbs-chinese-new-year-holidays-lawrence-wong-1784181  Link [3]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030109/https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/government-economy/we-dont-intend-to-relax-further-says-lawrence-wong-as-covid-curbs-look-set-to  Link [4]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030130/https://www.gov.sg/article/safe-management-measures-and-chinese-new-year  ____________________  *** Please refer to previous notes:    No Coding Changes to the period of 01-06 January 2022. Recent updates from the government states that in light of the Omicron variant, the current Covid-19 safety measurements will remain unchanged right into the Chinese New Year (CNY) period - this commences on the 01-02 February 2022 and normally the period stretches for 14 days.  ________________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore's current set of Covid-19 safe management rules will stay in place during the upcoming Chinese New Year period from Feb 1, in view of a likely surge of infections brought about by the new Omicron variant, said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong on Wednesday (Jan 5). Group sizes for gathering and dining at restaurants have been capped at five since November, when Singapore emerged from an outbreak caused by the earlier Delta variant. Mr Wong, who is a co-chair of the multi-ministry task force handling Covid-19, said during a press conference that the present posture would be maintained as he could not imagine the Omicron wave passing before Chinese New Year."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220106084209/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/current-covid-19-rules-will-stay-during-cny-period-in-view-of-omicron-wave-lawrence-wong.    ______________________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 18 Dec 2021:  No coding changes for the period of 14-18 Dec 2021. _  __________   ***Please refer to notes dated 13 Dec 2021:  Face masks continue to be mandated any time outside of the home. _    ______________    Quote (1): ""How does COVID-19 spread? Current evidence suggests that transmission of COVID-19 occurs primarily through the respiratory droplets of infected people, which are expelled when an infected person coughs, sneezes, talks or sings. These respiratory droplets can reach the eyes, nose or mouth of a susceptible person directly or indirectly (via contaminated surfaces), resulting in infection.  Airborne transmission of the virus can occur in health care settings where aerosol-generating procedures are performed. While there have been limited reports of airborne transmission outside of health care settings internationally, its role and extent are under further study. MOH will continue to monitor the evidence as it emerges.  To reduce the risk of spread, members of public must wear a mask outside the home and observe safe distancing. Individuals should also observe good hand hygiene and avoid crowded spaces if possible.""      Link (1): https://web.archive.org/web/20211206075819/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/general

No coding changes for the period of 12-22 Feb 2022.  _______________________    Quote (1):  "It is mandatory for all persons who are 6 years old and above to wear a mask when leaving their homes. Masks help to reduce the expulsion and transmission of droplets, which is the predominant route of transmission of COVID-19. It is therefore important for you to wear a mask, so that you will not spread the infection to others if you are infected. This is important even if you feel well, because you may be infected but asymptomatic."    Link (1):  http://web.archive.org/web/20220222052244/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/general/faqs---masks-and-personal-protective-equipment-%28ppe%29

Universal availability for the initial regimen with booster shots allowed for prioritized groups [Link (2)]. The current validity duration of the initial vaccine regimen is under review - in order for individuals to maintain a ""fully vaccinated"" status, they may be required to take booster shots or to have a second regimen in a year's time [Link (3)]. Children under 12 are currently under review to possibly receive the vaccine in the future [Link (4)].  The government has recently announced that children from 5-11 years old are not able to take part in the national vaccination program. It campaign has not yet begun but is schedule to by the end of 2021. [Link (5)] .  Additionally, vaccines for children aged 5-11 years old are now eligible for the covid vaccine under the National Vaccination Programme. [Link (6)]    Groups: Universal availability    Vaccines:    1. Moderna (Government Funded)   2. Pfizer-BioNTech/Comirnaty (Government Funded)   3. Sinovac-Coronavac (Government Funded) [7] - 3 doses required for Full Vax status [8]  4. Sinopharm (Government Funded/Individual cost through the Private sector only ) - SAR    5. AstraZeneca (Individual cost through the Private sector only ) - SAR      *SAR = Special Access Route  ____________________________________      Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20211116203225/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/vaccination   Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20211014035410/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid-19-vaccine-booster-shots-seniors-immunocompromised-elderly-care-homes-2154791   Link (3): http://web.archive.org/web/20211112144700/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid19-vaccine-expiry-date-365-days-booster-moh-2308821   Link (4): http://web.archive.org/web/20211119083158/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/kkh-recruiting-children-aged-5-to-11-for-covid-19-vaccination-trial   Link (5): http://web.archive.org/web/20211213092117/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/moh-covid-19-vaccination-children-singapore-2372631  Link (6): http://web.archive.org/web/20220102123050/https://www.moe.gov.sg/news/press-releases/20211221-protecting-our-children-from-covid-19-with-vaccination-for-5-to-11-year-olds  Link (7): http://web.archive.org/web/20220207085503/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/vaccination  Link (8): http://web.archive.org/web/20220207085505/https://www.vaccine.gov.sg/health-advisory/

No Coding changes for the period of 29 January to 07 February 2022.  _____________________________________  ***Please refer to notes dated 28 January 2022:    Regardless of vaccination status, there are strict rules for each group of individuals before being able to enter nursing homes and hospitals to visit the elderly.    From the 24 of January, all in-persons will be suspended for 4 weeks until 20 February 2022 in light of the current omicron wave in Singapore.  _________________    Quote (1):  "[Updated 21 January 2022]    To better protect our patients and healthcare workers, particularly in settings with vulnerable persons, in-person visits to all hospital wards1 and residential care homes will be suspended for a period of four weeks, from 24 January to 20 February 2022 (both dates inclusive).    During this period, hospitals and homes can make assessments on a case-by-case basis to allow in-person visits for exceptional cases. More details for visits to hospitals and homes can be found below.    Pre-visit testing requirements at hospitals and homes    Visitors who are allowed into hospital wards and homes will be required to show a valid negative ART result obtained within the last 24 hours of each visit. All tests are to be self-funded by the visitor. This is a mandatory requirement for all visitors regardless of vaccination status, except for persons who have recovered from COVID-19 and are able to present a valid Pre-Event Test (PET) exemption notice2.   Fully vaccinated or medically ineligible visitors can perform an unsupervised self-administered ART or opt for an ART administered by MOH-approved COVID-19 test providers (including tests performed at Quick Test Centres) to fulfil the pre-visit testing requirement. Those who opt to undergo unsupervised self-administered ART will be required to show evidence of a valid ART result, e.g. present a time-stamped photo of the dated ART result and photo ID for verification prior to entry.  Non-fully vaccinated visitors would be required to show results of ART administered or supervised by MOH-approved COVID-19 test providers (including Quick Test Centres). Results from unsupervised self-administered ART will not be accepted for this group of visitors.    In-person visits at hospitals  The following patient groups will continue to be allowed visitors on a case-by case basis, as assessed by the hospitals:   a. Patients who are in critical condition;    b. Paediatric patients;   c. Birthing/post-partum mothers; and    d. Patients requiring additional care support from caregivers. Examples of caregivers include those providing assistance to inpatients who have mental incapacities or family members who are undergoing caregiver training to better  care for their loved ones after hospital discharge.      The above patient groups would be allowed only one pre-designated visitor, with one visit per day. Patients who are in critical condition may be allowed up to five pre-designated visitors, with a maximum of two visitors at the patientâs bedside at any one time.  All visitors approved to enter hospital wards must don face masks with good filtration capability at all times. These include surgical masks and reusable masks that are made of two layers of fabric. Visitors are reminded not to eat or drink in the hospital wards or use the patientsâ toilets in the wards. They should also avoid sitting on patientsâ beds.    1Includes public acute hospitals, community hospitals and private hospitals   2 Recovered individuals (within last 180 days) can obtain a PET Exemption Notice from any clinic  offering ART or Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) testing services." This is to protect Singapore's healthcare capacity and vulnerable seniors, the Ministry of Health (MOH) said on Friday (Jan 21). The suspension will last from next Monday (Jan 24) to Feb 20." No Coding changes for the period of 08 - 11 February 2022.  _____________________________________  ***Please refer to notes dated 28 January 2022:    Regardless of vaccination status, there are strict rules for each group of individuals before being able to enter nursing homes and hospitals to visit the elderly.    From the 24 of January, all in-persons will be suspended for 4 weeks until 20 February 2022 in light of the current omicron wave in Singapore.  _________________    Quote (1):  "[Updated 21 January 2022]    To better protect our patients and healthcare workers, particularly in settings with vulnerable persons, in-person visits to all hospital wards1 and residential care homes will be suspended for a period of four weeks, from 24 January to 20 February 2022 (both dates inclusive).    During this period, hospitals and homes can make assessments on a case-by-case basis to allow in-person visits for exceptional cases. More details for visits to hospitals and homes can be found below.    Pre-visit testing requirements at hospitals and homes    Visitors who are allowed into hospital wards and homes will be required to show a valid negative ART result obtained within the last 24 hours of each visit. All tests are to be self-funded by the visitor. This is a mandatory requirement for all visitors regardless of vaccination status, except for persons who have recovered from COVID-19 and are able to present a valid Pre-Event Test (PET) exemption notice2.   Fully vaccinated or medically ineligible visitors can perform an unsupervised self-administered ART or opt for an ART administered by MOH-approved COVID-19 test providers (including tests performed at Quick Test Centres) to fulfil the pre-visit testing requirement. Those who opt to undergo unsupervised self-administered ART will be required to show evidence of a valid ART result, e.g. present a time-stamped photo of the dated ART result and photo ID for verification prior to entry.  Non-fully vaccinated visitors would be required to show results of ART administered or supervised by MOH-approved COVID-19 test providers (including Quick Test Centres). Results from unsupervised self-administered ART will not be accepted for this group of visitors.    In-person visits at hospitals  The following patient groups will continue to be allowed visitors on a case-by case basis, as assessed by the hospitals:   a. Patients who are in critical condition;    b. Paediatric patients;   c. Birthing/post-partum mothers; and    d. Patients requiring additional care support from caregivers. Examples of caregivers include those providing assistance to inpatients who have mental incapacities or family members who are undergoing caregiver training to better  care for their loved ones after hospital discharge.      The above patient groups would be allowed only one pre-designated visitor, with one visit per day. Patients who are in critical condition may be allowed up to five pre-designated visitors, with a maximum of two visitors at the patientâs bedside at any one time.  All visitors approved to enter hospital wards must don face masks with good filtration capability at all times. These include surgical masks and reusable masks that are made of two layers of fabric. Visitors are reminded not to eat or drink in the hospital wards or use the patientsâ toilets in the wards. They should also avoid sitting on patientsâ beds.    1Includes public acute hospitals, community hospitals and private hospitals   2 Recovered individuals (within last 180 days) can obtain a PET Exemption Notice from any clinic  offering ART or Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) testing services." Universal availability for the initial regimen with booster shots allowed for prioritized groups [Link (2)]. The current validity duration of the initial vaccine regimen is under review - in order for individuals to maintain a ""fully vaccinated"" status, they may be required to take booster shots or to have a second regimen in a year's time [Link (3)]. Children under 12 are currently under review to possibly receive the vaccine in the future [Link (4)].  The government has recently announced that children from 5-11 years old are not able to take part in the national vaccination program. It campaign has not yet begun but is schedule to by the end of 2021. [Link (5)] .  Additionally, vaccines for children aged 5-11 years old are now eligible for the covid vaccine under the National Vaccination Programme. On 20th January 2022, the Ministry of Health issued guidance that it will not order schools to close unless clusters of Covid-19 cases turn up. Measures would also be targeted within the school; if cases are found, a particular classroom or grade might be ordered to close for cleaning for 3 days, rather than the entire school.      Additionally, the National News Bureau of Thailand reported on 18th January 2022 that many schools in Thailand have resumed onsite classes, but are also staggering the return of their students to reduce crowding. Some schools are for example, requiring some grades to remain fully online, while the rest of the students alternate the days that they attend in person, so that only 30% of the student body is present at any one time. Therefore, although many schools are open, significant public health precautions have been incorporated.     1.	The Nation | Thailand article: âNo school shutdowns unless clusters emergeâ: https://web.archive.org/web/20220124150009/https://www.nationthailand.com/in-focus/40011306  2.	National News Bureau of Thailand article: âSchools hold first on-site classes of 2022â: https://web.archive.org/web/20220124145222/https://thainews.prd.go.th/en/news/detail/TCATG220118165943585

Schools in Bangkok have reopened on 1 Feb 2022. All people entering school premises must undergo thermal screening and practice social distancing. Class size is limited to 25 students. More blended learning will take place in the future.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210201062721/https://thainews.prd.go.th/en/news/detail/TCATG210201132544155
No policy change.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210201062721/https://thainews.prd.go.th/en/news/detail/TCATG210201132544155  https://archive.ph/RhHBL

From 24 January, 2022, restaurants and eateries in the Blue Zone destinations that have received the SHA Plus certification (Ministry of Tourism and Sports) or the Thai Stop COVID 2 Plus standard (Ministry of Public Health) will be allowed to serve dine-in customers alcoholic beverages up until 23.00 Hrs.    However, all types of entertainment venues, including pubs, bars, and karaoke shops nationwide are to remain closed until further notice.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220124185839/https://www.tatnews.org/2022/01/thailand-adjusts-covid-19-curbs-nationwide-from-24-january-2022/

No policy updates.    On 18th January 2022, the Bangkok Metropolitan Administration (BMA) announced that it will cancel the Chinese New Year celebrations that it normally organises at Bangkok's Yaowarat Road/Chinatown, due to concerns over the Omicron variant. However, apart from this specific government-organised event in Bangkok, have not found evidence of the BMA or other Thai authorities requiring other public events held by private actors to be cancelled.     The government offered safety tips for Chinese New Year, but there is no mention of a ban on public events. It is phrased as âadviceâ for people to generally avoid crowded places. Therefore, coded as 1G because there is a recommendation to avoid crowds, but without an actual requirement to cancel events.     Archived sources:   1. The Royal Thai Government maintained the designation of 8 âBlue Zoneâ provinces and 18 provinces with âBlue Zoneâ districts, while redesignating 25 provinces as Areas Under Stringent Surveillance or yellow zone and continued existing measures in 44 provinces as Controlled Areas or orange zone, effective from 24 January, 2022.    Meetings and events in hotels, trade centres, convention halls, and similar venues can be organised for less than 1,000 attendees, and under stringent disease prevention and control guidelines. Meanwhile, provinces in the orange zone can arrange more engaging activities; such as, sports tournaments, food fairs, and the like for no more than 1,000 attendees.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220124185839/https://www.tatnews.org/2022/01/thailand-adjusts-covid-19-curbs-nationwide-from-24-january-2022/

No policy updtes.    Thailand is presently at level 3, out of its 5-level alert system. At level 3, government advisories may recommend measures like working from home, but it is not mandated. There are also no curfews for Covid-19 management in effect. Many economic sectors and activities that are not considered essential services have been allowed to operate/take place. Quarantines are compulsory for travellers to Thailand. There are however, differentiated rules based on vaccination status, with stricter rules for unvaccinated people (the "Alternative Quarantine" scheme). Unvaccinated travellers to Thailand must quarantine for 10 days and undergo 2 PCR tests upon arrival. Before travelling to Thailand, a negative PCR test taken no earlier than 72 hours prior to departure is also required, except for travellers under the age of 6. Travellers from any country in the world can enter via this scheme.     Additional notes: Vaccinated travellers can undergo a shorter 7-day quarantine, but must also take pre-departure and post-arrival PCR tests. The Thai government has announced that it will further relax international travel controls, but these will come into effect only on 1st February 2022.     Archived sources:  1.	Thai Government Public Relations Department, Facebook post (English):  https://archive.vn/2RqQd   2.	Royal Thai Embassy, London: âRequirements for foreigners travelling to Thailand during COVID-19 travel restrictionâ (English):  https://archive.vn/E9ytc   3.	Royal Thai Embassy, Beijing: "Entry requirements for entry to Thailand with effect from 11th January 2022" (English & Chinese): https://archive.vn/cZh8Y  4.	Royal Thai Embassy, Canberra: âSchemes for entering Thailandâ (English): https://archive.vn/nlmpY  5.	Tourism Authority of Thailand (English): https://archive.vn/i8WT6

Effective February 1, 2022, Thailand will resume registrations for the Test & Go program that allows fully vaccinated travellers from any country to enjoy quarantine-free entry. Additional entry requirements through this program include submitting proof of payment for two separate nights of accommodation on Day 1 and Day 5 at government-approved hotels and proof of payment for 2 RT-PCR tests. For travellers under 18 years of age, travelling with parents or guardians, the quarantine period is within the same duration as their parents or guardians.    Quarantine of 10 days is required for unvaccinated travellers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220203172349/https://www.tatnews.org/2022/01/thailand-resumes-test-go-scheme-reopens-pattaya-and-ko-chang-sandbox-from-1-february-2022/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220204220639/https://th.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220205235707/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/thailand/entry-requirements
No change  https://web.archive.org/web/20220204220639/https://th.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

No policy update.  On 24th January, the 4th phase of âKhon La Khreungâ, the Thai governmentâs co-payment subsidy scheme was approved. Through this scheme, the government co-pays 50% of certain living costs (food, drink and other goods and services), capped at a maximum of 150 baht/day. Phase 3 had expired on 31st December 2021, and Phase 4 will come into effect from 1st February 2022 to 30th April 2022. Coded as 1A because there are still other ongoing schemes to provide income support (such as to the nightlife workers, as mentioned in the 18th January 2022 note).     Archived sources:   1. No policy update.  Present testing policy: lateral flow/rapid antigen tests are available to be purchased at subsidised prices. The government has also distributed some tests for free. Anyone who tests positive on a rapid test is supposed to report it and obtain a PCR test (administered by a health worker) to confirm the result.     Free PCR tests are also being offered to Thai citizens and foreign travellers who require it under the Test & Go scheme, regardless of symptoms.     Additional notes: However, there have been difficulties caused by the shortage of rapid test kits, due to the spread of Omicron increasing demand. Such shortages could impact access to PCR tests, since a positive lateral test is the gateway to getting a PCR test.     Archived source:   1. No policy change. News articles detail enforcement responses by authorities over failure of tourists to wear masks in public, and complaints by parents referencing continued strict mask rules in schools for students. Thailand travel advice by foreign missions also continue to mention mask requirements and reference possible liability for fines. Additionally, on the Thai Governmentâs Public Relations Department official Facebook page; the banner states âSTOP COVIDâ¦keep wearing a mask at all times when in publicâ as of 24th January 2022.     The phrasing "advised" to "wear a mask in public" rather than "compulsory" has been used in some other government communications that were published in English, but have not found announcements actually announcing relaxation of mask rules that were instituted in 2021, so interpreted as no national policy change based on overall picture of sources.     1. No update.    The government announced on 24th January 2022 that it will start vaccinating children aged 5-11 for the first time, from 1st February 2022 onwards. Although this group is subsumed within the larger 5-15 years old age bracket for the purposes of the dataset, the vaccines had previously been available only for children aged 12 and above.     Children aged 5-11 are not prioritised vis a vis other age brackets, as sufficient vaccines for adults are available. However, the government has said that within the 5-11 age group, it will focus on first vaccinating children who have underlying health conditions such as asthma and obesity. An initial shipment of 3 million Pfizer vaccines that will be arriving in late January is part of a larger vaccine procurement of 10 million.    Archived sources:  1. Thai Government Public Relations Department, post on official Twitter account: https://archive.vn/wDOgb   2. Bangkok Post: "Pfizer jabs for 5-11s to arrive next week.": https://archive.ph/N4knC   3. Reuters: "Thai agency approves Pfizer vaccine for use in children aged 5-11": https://archive.vn/JRURK
No policy change.   https://archive.ph/RhHBL   https://archive.fo/cn7XN

Additional notes regarding opening of vaccination to children aged 5-11: These children will not be prioritised vis a vis other age brackets, as sufficient vaccines for adults are available. However, the government has said that within this age group, it will prioritise children who have underlying health conditions such as asthma and obesity.    Children will receive two Pfizer (Comirnaty) jabs three to 12 weeks apart. Meanwhile, Thailand is currently registering Sinovac vaccine for use in younger children aged over three.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220201015024/https://www.nationthailand.com/in-focus/40011747

The command center announced that it will maintain the second-level epidemic alert standard from 8 Feb 2022 to 28 Feb 2022. From 16 Nov 2021 onwards, leisure and entertainment venues with escort services can open for business if they meet the epidemic prevention measures:    From January 21, 2022, the public will go to "karaoke halls, dance halls, nightclubs, clubs, restaurants, bars, hotels (gallery), beauty salons (tourist haircuts, audio-visual grooming) and special coffee tea rooms, nightclubs, dance venues, In leisure and entertainment venues such as "Sannuan", the complete record of vaccination against COVID-19 should be presented before entry into activities and consumption.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220226054611/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Category/ListContent/EmXemht4IT-IRAPrAnyG9A?uaid=FNjpFKjhjxvQ-imhFpOjeA

From 8 Feb 2022 to 28 Feb 2022, the epidemic alert level will be maintained at level 2, and relevant measures and regulations will be adjusted or maintained as follows:   When formal filming or conducting of conversational work or activities such as sports, singing, photography, live broadcast, video recording, hosting, reporting, speeches, speeches, lectures, etc., the wearing of masks shall be restored. From 8 Feb 2022 to 28 Feb 2022, the epidemic alert level will be maintained at level 2, and relevant measures and regulations will be adjusted or maintained as follows:   Strengthen crowd control in stores, supermarkets and markets: indoor space of at least 1.5 meters/person (2.25 square meters/person), outdoor space of at least 1 meter/person (1 square meter/person); not open for tasting.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220226054611/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Category/ListContent/EmXemht4IT-IRAPrAnyG9A?uaid=FNjpFKjhjxvQ-imhFpOjeA

Taxis and public transport systems are operating normally in Taiwan. The wearing of face masks is mandatory on all public transport. If you use public transport and are not wearing a face mask, you may be fined up to NT$15,000.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220226054814/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/taiwan/coronavirus

No stay-at-home requirement according to the second-level epidemic alert standard.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220226054611/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Category/ListContent/EmXemht4IT-IRAPrAnyG9A?uaid=FNjpFKjhjxvQ-imhFpOjeA

Key measures of the covid relief package 4.0:  Accelerating relief for individuals: In addition to administering aid in accordance with last year's standards, a subsidy is available for families with students enrolled in elementary school and below, as well as disabled students in junior and senior high school and the first three years of five-year junior colleges. Living allowances are also going out to children, young people, the elderly and the disabled in low to middle-low income households. Excluding those above a certain income, agricultural and fisheries workers, the self-employed, and workers without fixed employers also receive living allowances.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116055359/https://english.ey.gov.tw/News3/9E5540D592A5FECD/10e57174-8e16-4710-b4ac-9882bd8db7de

Financial Relief    Three Ways to Help from Public Banks    1. Policy Lending Package: Support SMEs funding to operate business.    2. Loan Extension: Companies or individuals can apply to defer principal repayment or extend loan.    3. Credit card payment deferral: Individuals can apply to defer card payment without penalty and interest.    The measures of reducing interest rate from public banks    Residential Loan (For all loans): 0.25% lower since 2020/9/30  Consuming Loan (For all loans): 0.25% lower since 2020/9/30 (including credit card, unsecured loan, car loan)    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116055846/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/taiwan-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html
Dedicated websites amongst them Taiwan Centre for Disease Control.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220226055653/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En

Self-paid testing is available for both emergency and outpatient. e.g.     (1) To enter other countries for the compassionate reasons listed above.    (2) Job requirements.    (3) To study abroad.    (4) Foreign nationals, mainland Chinese, or Hong Kong and Macao residents who will depart from Taiwan.    (5) Family members of people traveling abroad for the reasons listed above.    (6) Approved by the Central Epidemic Command Center.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220226055641/https://www6.vghtpe.gov.tw/reg/ctestAnn.do?lang=EN

COVID-19 vaccine appointments for the first shot, second shot, or booster shot are widely available to people aged 12 or older.    Eligibility: individuals who registered on the System before 6 a.m. on December 13 and meet any of the following criteria:  1. The first dose of the BNT vaccine: people aged 12 or older (born on December 16, 2009, or earlier).  2. The second dose of the BNT vaccine: people aged 18 or older (born on December 31, 2003, or earlier) who received their first dose of BNT before November 18 (inclusive).  3. Mixing of AZ with a second dose of the BNT vaccine: people aged 18 or older (born on December 16, 2003, or earlier) who received their first dose of AZ before October 21 (inclusive).    Remarks: The 23rd phase of the publicly funded vaccine platform has been opened since 16 Feb 2022    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116062114/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En/Bulletin/Detail/kaT7wZ1ubFZzyHlWUQsENg?typeid=158  https://web.archive.org/web/20220226060301/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Category/ListContent/EmXemht4IT-IRAPrAnyG9A?uaid=Z0Az4TD0aBC1AsNJBlqSlA

Level Two alert still on. From 24 Jan 2022, the COVID-19 response measures of residential long-term care institutions nationwide will be adjusted. The key points are as follows:  1. Visitor management: Visits are suspended except in exceptional circumstances. "Officials have declared a public health emergency through at least July 31. Inbound commercial international flights and cruise ships remain banned, though international cargo flights continue. Authorities are prohibiting nonresidents from entering the country. Officials have resumed repatriation flights, but citizens from designated high-risk countries are not allowed to enter until further notice. Fully vaccinated travelers from low- and medium-risk locations can enter the country with a COVID-19 test conducted within 72 hours before departure. Officials require arriving passengers to quarantine for 14 days, with COVID-19 tests within 24 hours of and day 8 after arrival."    Source- GardaWorld  https://archive.fo/I7gXj
